reviewText: Hard Reset is like some strange and wondrous artifact from an alternate universe, one where technology continued to advance after the 90's, but none of the corridor shooter tropes we see in games nowadays ever caught on.  It combines oldschool FPS gameplay from the Unreal era with shiny modern visuals, then adds a light sprinkling of modern shooter mechanics (a regenerating shield meter, two basic weapons that can be upgraded into several very different forms) that enhance the core gameplay without overwhelming it.  Graphic novel-style cutscenes between levels tell a serviceable cyberpunk tale that provides context for all the shooting, but once the action starts, the story elements have the good grace to step aside and let you get down to business.  The levels are open and reward exploration, with secrets to find and explosive items scattered about that let you set up environmental kills - another nod to oldschool design.\n\nIf you have even the slightest interest in oldschool FPS's, you owe it to yourself to check out Hard Reset.

reviewText:
If you're reading this, you already amaze me. This game is ludicrously obscure.
Simply put, Hard Reset is Bulletstorm done right. Made by 35 people on a budget of less than 5 million bucks, you can see the personality in this game.
The gameplay is a solid case of using the environment to your advantage, and the soundtrack is some of the best cyberpunk-esque you're going to hear in a long, long time.
The graphics put a very large number of triple a games to shame, and all in all the gameplay, sound design and aesthetic come together to make grenading a large group of enemies very, very, very satisfying.
My one and only complaint, as you tend to have with budget titles, is that the story was visibly handled after the rest of the game, being told almost entirely through a comic book style series of cutscenes with voice acting (that sometimes doesn't even match up with the guy voicing the character in gameplay) that doesn't exactly go out of its way to win any awards.
Aside from all this, the developers get major kudos for releasing extension DLC a good 8 months after the game's release completely free.

Hard Reset is a beautiful snack for folks who love retro shooters the likes of Doom, Serious Sam and Duke Nukem, but anyone else should steer clear, as this thing is a hell of an obscure niche title.

reviewText:
I kind of hate this game.  Playing it well requires constantly harnessing the diversity of your arsenal, and I am just not good at fighting with more than one gun at a time.  It is often difficult for me to assess a situation rapidly enough in the middle of battleâ€”while my brain is consumed with the effort of dodging, shooting, and navigating to health and ammo pickups just in the nick of timeâ€”to see an opportunity for a better tactic represented by one of my other weapons.

So it has been an extremely frustrating experience, particularly because I stubbornly insist on sticking with Hard difficulty to the end (just regular Hard, mind you; there is worse available, if you wish for it).  I can only play one level per session because it's such an exhausting ordeal, and I've spent the entire latter half of the game wishing it would end already.

Yet, objectively, I recognize that Hard Reset is a very good first-person shooter of the old school style.  There are moments when I actually manage to adapt and perform well, and it is quite gratifying.  I certainly do recommend it.  Just be honest with yourself about who you really are before you make that purchase.

reviewText:
Went in with no expectations and left 8 hours later think... that was a bloody fun game!

So, imagine a movie from the 1980s, it's about Humans fighting machines, only the movie isn't Terminator, it's some B-Movie Polish Sci-Fi movie starring a guy that vaguly looks like Michael Biehn. They wanted to hire Michael Biehn to be the actor, but sadly the producer had spent the entire budget on the SFX - that's basically Hard Reset.

Forget about trying to make sense of the story, which is pretty off the wall and has liberal use of swear words (like a teenager out of earshot of their parents). For this game isn't about an deep storyline where the plot is a social commentary - no; this game is about one thing... shooting robots. Lots of robots, and causing some really impressive explosions.
That's where Hard Reset excels - making things explode.
It has some of the best lighting effects I've seen in a computer game, which it uses it effectively throughout the game. I'm not one to really care or comment on lighting in computer games, but for once I'm willing to give it a go.

The neon world (insert Blade Runner comparison here) contrasts well with the dark gritty under-streets you start in. Yet that isn't the most impressive part of the lighting, it's the lightning that comes from your gun, or sub-stations that spew out lightning shocks that attack the robots and cause environmental damage. Wonderful stuff. Or the huge fireball explosions that emit from Gas Mains and Pipes. It's all nice stuff.

Also, like all good 80's Movies this game plays host to one amazing soundtrack that underscores the entire gameplay experience. Like classic shooters before it the music kicks in when the action ramps out and dies out as the last robot's motorservers slowly whine down as it dies in front of you. It's hard to describe the soundtrack, but it fits like a glove.

Basically this is a First Person Shooter. It's not ashamed of being a FPS; it grabs the genre and runs with it, only it doesn't stop after the first down... no it continues. It doesn't attempt to re-invent the wheel at any point in the game, so it might get a little stale towards the end, but for me the fun lasted a good 7 hours. It was just refreshing to play a game that knew what it was and tried to be the best it could be at it's genre.
I'm not going to claim it's an 'old school' FPS, as it isn't, but there are some nice nods to previous FPS throughout the game that fans of the genre will pick up on.

The biggest compliment I can really give this game is that I expected nothing, and came away wanting to raise awareness of the game and get more people playing it.

reviewText:
Quality over Quantity

To say that this game is short is an understatement.

This game occupies 3056 MB of space. Yeah, go figure.
That's why they decided to not waste a DVD on it.

THE POSITIVES

1. This is a PC exclusive (a rare breed these days) with the fully optimized graphic options. The controls are smooth and responsive. I also found myself being swept over with feeling again and again that I was playing a PC exclusive. It is worth paying money to have that feeling - that's what the consoles are turning us into.

2. Your character is not a mute like in most shooters.

3. I will say that the new engine delivers. The distant vistas, the textures, the physics, the explosions, the graphics in general are great, DirectX 9.0c and all. The details are meticulous especially up close, you can see the tiniest scratches and dents on the objects.

4. True, there is no health regeneration.

5. The game runs smoothly, no FPS spikes, the dozen or so near-simultaneous explosions are an eye-candy.

6. Upgrades for the 10 weapons as well as the gear is always welcome. However, just like in Witcher 2, as soon as you finish upgrading one tech tree" or one upgradable branch the game ends.

7. Finally
date: this game has style. Even though the streets and the slums are empty except for the rampant robots
recommended:
the peculiar sci-fi world where humanity has learned to download its consciousness into the computer is pretty cool to ponder about.


The minuses:

1. No crouching.

2. No melee (I doubt it's useful against the machines anyway but quite often they do get close enough to ram you)

3. You cannot see your legs and you do not cast a shadow.

4. BUT there is SHIELD regeneration - something the previewers failed to mention. So the concept of the old school no-health-regeneration kinda goes out the window.

5. No reloading.

6. The story is kinda blah.

7. The amount of enemy types is very limited.

8. The jump is realistic. And I by that I mean it is practically nonexistent. You cannot jump over the rails and some other objects even when it seems like you can to save time.

reviewText:
+ Excellent sound effects
+ Sharp, crisp visuals and weather effects
+ Gunplay is solid and responsive
+ Partially dustructive environments make for some creative means of handling enemies
+ Firearms are very well-done; you essentially get two guns, but can upgrade them with several different firing modes (ultimately lacks variety, but it was designed in such a way that it did not hurt the game, and in fact helped it in many ways)
+ Upgrade system, and terminal interactions in general, are amazing and a pleasure to interact with
+ A lot of tongue-in-cheek material, such as the necessant advertising prevailent throughout the game's world
+ Extremely fast and exciting pace; game boasts gratuitous ammunition and no reload (relying instead on generous item drops)
+ Secrets and hidden objects in game are fun to find and collect
+ Comic-styled intermissions are a nice touch and very well done; sports surprisingly competent voice-acting
+ Sharp, crisp textures
+ Gorgeous industrial environment designs; game's design lends itself strongly to cyberpunk themes, and does so very well
+ Very, very well optimized, and boasting of some top-shelf lighting (uses HavoK engine)

- No objective markers (this will not be a problem 90% of the time, as the stages are moderately linear, but there were a few frustrating occasions where I lamented the lack of some kind of visible marker)
- Game world is not populated at all; even though this was the intention, it makes the whole world feel empty, and therefore fails to make one feel as though their actions have real consequence, as though nothing is really at stake
- Poor variation in enemy models
- Not very competent storytelling; plot is muddled and confusing, and the ending did little to tie up loose ends

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Hard Reset is a game that very clearly sets out to evoke the more generic and traditional FPS style of yesteryear with the visuals aesthetic of a more modern game.  It does that pretty well and it's a fun and enjoyable game, but it fails in a few areas that are somewhat glaring, and it does have it's problems.  If you're about to stop reading this review because I'm not going to be 100% positive about this review, well, that's your perrogative, but I'm not saying it's by any means a bad game.  It's a good game, bordering on great, but it has some foilbes that hold it back from true excellence.

The aesthetic of the game is probably one of the parts it really does very well, and it extends entirely through the game.  It has a very heavy cyberpunk aesthetic, loading screens are hidden behind very artfully done comic book intermissions, and the visuals of the game are absolutely gorgeous.  It has an actually fairly strong story for a FPS (which .. admittedly isn't saying much), and things thematically are pretty strong and engaging.  However, there's two fairly large problems with this aesthetic and both of them essentially boil down to making things hard to distinguish.  First of all, having robotic enemies in a game level that largely involves a lot of technological set pieces makes it very difficult to distinguish enemies at a glance.  Compare this to something like Painkiller or Serious Sam where the enemies are relatively speaking very easy to distinguish from the scenery.  Also, having electrical particle effects for hit confirmations on enemies when the destructible environment pieces also give off the same or similar particle effects make it difficult to say whether you are hitting an enemy with your shots, or the environment. The two guns in their different modes also are difficult to distinguish what mode they are in just by looking at them.  They do have differences in the modes, but they are subtle and hard to tell at a quick glance.

The gunplay is simultaneously a very strong element of the game but also very disappointing.  The fact that the two weapons in their different modes handle so well, with a tangiable feel of weight, satisfying visuals, and good sound assets, only serves to accentuate my disappointment and frustration with them having the two weapon mode system.  I don't feel the system adds anything to the game of value in this case.  In some games with a two weapon system what you have is a large weapon selection and you have to choose the two of them that you feel best work for the tactical situations and enemies that you will be facing.  However, with all the different modes available at all times, I kind of am left in agreement with TotalBiscuit's comment in his first impressions that it seems like they used the two weapon mode so that they didn't have to create a series of different weapon models.  It's unfortunate.  These weapons would have been easier - and truer to the 'old school' FPS, if they were simply seperate weapons.

The level design is a fairly strong aspect of the game, with lots of areas to explore and a large amount of secrets to find in each.  I like the feeling in several of the levels that you are actually in coherent areas which actually make sense in canon as well; for example one section being a little shanty-town of trailers where people live.  It evokes memories of the level design of Duke Nukem 3D, which is a comparison I make as highest praise, as that was a high point in FPS level design.  The Levellord was a master of the craft.

One thing that bears touching on to is that the overall pacing of the levels and the game in general is executed tremendously well.  There's a feeling of momenteum to the game that keeps things going at a decent clip unless you pause to go rummaging and every time I would think to myself that the enemy variety is thinning out there'd be a new enemy, and every time I started feeling comfortable with the level of difficulty the game would ramp it up again.

All in all a very well-crafted game with a good theme let down by a couple of fairly large issues that don't stop it from being a very good game and well worth your time and money.

I must start by stating a little spoiler about this game's mechanics that i think is very important to understand as it is so dominating in this game. The mechanic in question is the constant 'jump-scare' type of enemy spawning in the levels. Not once during the main or DLC part of the game does the player initiate combat. reviewText:
Flying Wild Hog are a developer I've learned to love because of their unrelenting old-school design philosophy. They hand you a variety of interesting and unique weapons, add in a no-nonsense upgrade system, then throw you into a well detailed and absolutely gorgeous world and throw large numbers of fairly challenging enemies at you to overcome until they turn you into a badass. Coming out a year before the equally awesome Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset is an arcadey, clunky first-person romp through a near-future, lightly-cyberpunk city that flew almost completely under the radar.

HighlightsMuch like Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset is a game that puts everything together really well, and gives a strong level of immersion that's missing from most games these days. I caught myself feeling like I was a detective inside a Blade Runner movie, trying to figure out what was going on while fighting off hoards of robots and passing through grimy city streets under the classy neon embankments, which, at times, is a real pleasure.

* The Flying Wild Hog Engine was built specifically for this title and is absolutely gorgeous while still performing really well
* The production value is clearly high, and it feels a lot more solid and well designed than just about any other indie title
* Extremely good content updates and freely released DLC which adds to the game deserve special mention

Mistakes
The settings and characters for this game give a ton of possibility and are really a blank canvas. It's a shame then, that what could've been an extra special experience ended up being merely an above average game due to a very forgettable plot and story and Comic-book intro scenes and good voice acting help the world come alive, but don't add much to the story or suspense.

* Feels like a corridor shooter at times and tends to feel very samey towards the end, despite the wide variety of weapons and upgrades
* For an FPS, it has lacklustre boss fights and a forgettable ending purely because of the lack of consequence, again because of the story

Recommendations
Priced at Â£9.99/13.49â‚¬/$14.99 at the time of review and clocking in at 8 hours gameplay, and with all the new content being released for free, Hard Reset is good value. It's also routinely on sale for as little as $4.99 on Steam and $1.49 from various Indie Bundle retailers.

* There's a fantastic Developer Artbook with characters, landscapes and plenty of concept art which is definitely worth a look. Available for free from here
* There's a free demo available on the Steam Store Page below which gives a good feel for the title

This game is a big f-cking metal boot stomping on your face from beginning to end.  I fricking love it.

reviewText:
Please excuse the lack of 100% achievements. I thought I could handle an FPS, but then I took insane for a spin. Hard Reset is like an unrelenting Olympic gymnastic coach who never gives you a moment's break. Are you sure you are out of the blast radius? ÐÐµÑ‚ . You miscalculated your shield recharge time? Nein. You thought a few heavy headshots would kill a charging monstrosity in time? ä¸. Did you think you found good cover from? No. In the first level of the game I felt like I deserved a parade at every check point.

But soon enough, I realized I was just being lazy. I loved Doom, Quake, and Unreal Tournament growing up. I had babied my FPS muscles and was suffering from atrophy in the L33t skillz area. With that in mind, I stepped up my game and started being more careful, more precise. I still died a lot, but now I was learning. I still felt supreme satisfaction, but I also gained a newfound respect in the balance. The game was trying to train me, and get me used to playing a shooter where I don't just respawn 2 seconds away, automatically regenarate all my health, or kill enemies in a few hits.

All that being said, Hard Reset is not perfect. The story could not really hold my attention, though the art was kind of nice. The load times can be a longer than comfortable. I despise the autosave system: I could have a perfect run all the way up to one point, only to be killed out of nowhere and have to try to recover my balance in the next load. I also feel like I should point out that it is not the hardest game ever made. I make it sound extremely tough, but I do not consider myself really great at shooters. Challenge is very subjective: I found Hotline MIami to be moderately diffiuclt on my old trackpad, but I cannot play War of the Roses or Megaman to save my life.

Hard Reset feels extremely refreshing and satisfying, while familiar at the same time. It has been bundled and been on sale frequently, so this is a solid, engaging experience worth checking out.

reviewText:
Pretty solid game. There were a lot of complaints about its length, but if you play through the base game and the DLC, you're in for probably 10 or more hours of shooting good times.

The weapons are interesting and the difficulty is high enough that I found I needed to use the crowd control mechanics extensively in order to get by.

I played the game on Hard, which is the default setting I use when playing shooters, and this one was by far the hardest one I've played in recent memory. There was one boss fight in the original chapters I died 49 times on!

One cool thing about the level design is that there are a lot of secrets tucked away in the levels which is something a lot of corridor shooters have lost over the years since the Doom II days. Some of the secrets are pretty easy to find, but some required really studying the options available in the room to figure out how to get to them.

I highly recommend advancing to the Rail Gun or the RPG as fast as possible (accomplish this by checking the pre-reqs on it and focusing on them as high priority upgrades). The rest of the weapons do not do enough damage to really chip through the harder enemies fast enough. Again, this was on Hard. Maybe Normal is a cakewalk, I dunno.

Overall, good game, probably didn't get the acknowledgement it deserved.

One final note - the story is nigh incomprehensible, the VO often cringeworthy, the cutscenes okay, but the Cyberpunk setting is cool and you don't need to understand the story to enjoy blowing up endless waves of robots with a creatively versatile arsenal.

reviewText:
A decent, challenging cyberpunk FPS. Hard Reset is a great looker, boasting both an amazing artstyle and great graphical fidelity. Nothing bad can also be said about the technical aspect either, since gunplay is solid and the weapon animations smooth. The soundtrack is okay and fits the game, albeit is nothing to write home about.

That being said, Hard Reset suffers from repetitiveness, especially in the later stages. Fighting bullet sponge enemies in similar, dark rooms can be fun for only so long. The game follows the Serious Sam formula of locking you in an arena with hordes of enemies, and that inevitably gets boring during long sessions. The game shines when you treat as a time killer you boot up every once and again, not when you marathon it from start to finish.
It should also be noted that Hard Reset gets really difficult at times. It is a challenging FPS for the veterans of the genre, not a game for newcomers.

While Hard Reset might not be worth the full price of 13,99â‚¬, don't hesitate to grab it when it's on at least -50% sale. It has flaws, but it's certainly not a bad game.

reviewText:
This game is a great cyberpunk themed shooter with some excellent gunplay and creative enemies. the game is set in a post-apocalyptic future where machines are trying to wipe out humans. you play as major Fletcher, who is trying to stop the machines. and that's about all there is to the story. there are a few plot twists here and there and the ending sets up a sequel, the story isn't the strong point of the game, it's all about the shooting.

the main part of the game is obviously shooting and hard reset is one of the best. all the weapons feel very responsive and have some very cool designs. the is plenty of enemy variety and some very creative/epic boss fights with giant machines. there are only 2 weapons in the game but each one has about 5 upgradable firing modes. for example you can make the plasma blaster shoot matrix style electricity.

Aesthetically it reminds me of films like the matrix and the fifth element. Graphically the game blew me away, it's gorgeous! every level has so much detail in everything and has great lighting especially in the subway levels. the game's also well optimized and ran at a constant 60 on my rig. the game also has some nice futuristic sounding music and overall the sound design is great. i highly recommend this game if you're into cyberpunk or just good fps.

reviewText:
Why don't I quickly check Hard Reset off the list next...

At least, that's what I thought. Instead I found Hard Reset to be euhm... rather... Hard. This game is not a walk in the park, and has quite a good length as well. I suggest reading a short guide before getting started maybe, unless of course you like diving in totally unprepared.

Anyhow, it's important to make the right weapon and character upgrades right from the start. The weapons you are given at the beginning are crap, and I almost never used them. Try to upgrade to the Electric Mortar and/or Grenade Launcher as quickly as you can because they are able to keep your enemies at a distance, able to contain them. When you let them surround you and get close, you will die! Especially the Mortar saved my â™¥â™¥â™¥ on more than one occasion. Also using environmental damage is key in this game because even with better weapons those damn robots, large large amounts of them, won't go down easily.

Hard Reset was not what I expected it to be, but when you start having control it's really fun. Always challenging and full of suspense tough. So keep getting NANO to upgrade yourself, use the environment and you will make it to the end.

reviewText:
There is a demo, try that and decide for yourself. This is a mixed review, there are many things I love and hate about this game.

It's hard on hard.
Bullet sponges everywhere.
Cool weapons; you only get two, but then you upgrade them to get many different weapons, although they share ammo.
Movement is slow and clunky. There is a sprint, but it locks you out of shooting and jumping. Platforming sections though rare and only for secrets are a pain since your character weighs a ton. Can't jump over knee-high walls, no crouching; so there are many places where it looks like you should be able to go and you can't.

The setting is super cool, interactable ads, and little kiosks that talk to you and try to sell you â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ as if you were a consumer, I only wish I could actually buy their hair-cream. There are big tv-screens that activate and show the news when you look at them, really neat.

The ingame menus for upgrades and pretty much anything are really cool; a holographic screen pops up in front of your character and your crosshair turns into a little hand cursor which you can use to interact. Kinda neat, get the demo to test it out.

My game stutters even though I get a constant +100fps on a 144hz monitor, gives me a headache, v-sync on or off, doesn't matter. Because of this I can only play for short periods, and I have less patience with this game than others because it physically hurts. Maybe I should stop playing altogether. The problems are present in the demo aswell, try that and if you have problems there, don't bother with the full version.

Fov slider is measured in vertical, prepare to use a calculator.

I'm getting frustrated with the bullet sponges, so I'm just going to lower the difficulty. Maybe then I'll like the game. There's a demo so try that, though be aware that the upgrades work differently in the demo than in the full game, they also come slower.

I want to like this game, the setting and the awesome guns, though there are some points that just drive me nuts. I would strongly suggest you try the demo, it throws two bullet sponges at you at the same time to give you a feel for what you're going to be dealing with depending on the difficulty.

I am not going to give up on this game, I paid for it, and so I want my enjoyment out of it, I just have to figure out if I like my cookies gooey or crunchy (gooey btw)

reviewText:
A quality single player shooter enhanced by additional levels appended onto the original base game, a.k.a. the extended edition.

Enemy variety could be more varied and the save system is based on checkpoints though they're liberal enough not to cause severe frustration though I have to admit to a couple of F-Bombs and ALT F4s.

The weapon system is based on 2 guns, each with multiple modes.  An interesting attempt to redefine the first person shooter but I think it fails as the system is needlessly clunky.  With the energy weapon in hand, selecting the rocket launcher requires a key press for the host weapon and another for the launcher mode.  Why?  In the heat of battle I felt like a circus performer.  What's worse is that I found the controls to be somewhat unresponsive, no doubt a purposeful design decision to negate any type of weapon mode key press while sprinting.

Despite the flaws, the well realized world reminded me of Blade Runner infused with a bit of Rapture.   The level design, graphics and solid shooting mechanics are enough reasons to play.  Oh did I mention the Quake like rail-gun.  My favorite weapon in the game, though like some of the other weapon modes there is a cool down so spamming anything but the base weapon modes is prohibited.

Weapon upgrades are acquired through upgrade terminals.  This mechanic does enhance the standard fps as the expenditure of the in game currency, called nano, allows for complete customization of your play-through.

The story I thought was well penned but is presented like a comic book.  There are multiple modes once your done with the game though I had little desire to partake.  One mode, called EX allows you to play the game with all weapon and defense upgrades in place.  Another mode, called Heroic allows for one save point at the beginning of the level.  The last is standard Survivor mode where the game throws waves of enemies at you.

I've read that the development team has roots in both BulletStorm and Painkiller.  The quality with which Hard Reset was constructed bears the fruit of that lineage.  It's a great shooter and worthy of your time and slot in your library.

reviewText:
A First-Person Shooter taking place in a dystopian 24th century setting where machines have taken over much of the planet and only a few scattered, human cities remain. WASD controls with mouse targeting.

There are two weapon types: a physical-based weapon for bullets, grenades and an RPG, and an energy-based weapon for plasma, electricity and laser railgun. Various alternate-weapon modes for scopes, stun and seeking rockets. Left-mouse for firing; right-mouse for alternate mode. You can also target objects in the environment to create explosions or electricity discharges that will destroy the enemies for you, but if you're too close, you'll take damage as well.

Ammo is plentiful as are healing power-ups, and the machines drop them as well. Lastly, there is a 'nano' resource that you need in order to unlock and upgrade weapons, and you can improve health, shield and recovery rates as well.

The enemies, of course, are the machines. They range from small anti-personnel devices with blades, saws and explosives, through human-sized robots using energy-blasts, rockets or brute-force ramming, up to huge, towering bosses with multiple, active weak-spots that need to be destroyed in order to take the thing down.

The saving is automatic at checkpoints and the zones between those checkpoints are pretty small, so reloading after defeat may cost you maybe five minutes of gameplay.

The graphics are good with decent explosions, discharges and flying pieces but not top-notch and no particle effects. Maxed-out, everything runs smoothly on Windows 7 with 16GB, a 990X CPU and SLI-coupled Nvidia 970's. There were no glitches, crashes, lock-ups or slow-downs.

The story that underlies the game is only partially present and things go on that don't make a lot of sense, nor does the ending resolve anything presented throughout the game, but it's enough of a shell to make the activities coherent and move the game forward.

It is a solid FPS, and mostly you'll be mowing waves of enemies down. You have to keep moving and using the environment for protection or you can easily be overwhelmed. Overall, it takes maybe 10 hours to complete a run-though, so it's a distraction for a single day, and there is some replayability though different weapon choices, as well as improving performance and finding all the scattered nano and secret areas. Nothing beyond nano is found in the secret areas, though.

Recommended.

reviewText:
Summary:
An old-school shooter to the core with beautiful cyberpunk environments, challenging combat, waves of enemies and a unique weapon system. Held back by awful voice acting, awful music, cheap cutscenes and a half-hearted story that explains little. Unfortunately, you often feel powerless against the chaos because there are no effective ways of dodging, it's easy to get trapped in a corner or have one of the countless explosive hazards set off a deadly chain reaction. Defeating certain enemies is very difficult without specific weapons which you may not have bought earlier. But if you're here purely for the vintage shooter action, you won't be disappointed, as it offers plenty of challenge.

The full story:
Hard Reset is a real mixed bag, and certainly not for everyone. It's an old-school shooter to the core, featuring only minimal controls and no extra bells and whistles, just you and waves of robotic enemies. The enemies, even on normal difficulty, can be quite challenging and are good at dodging attacks. They love to ambush you at every turn, flank you, and can quickly whittle down your health if you don't keep moving; you must always be ready for a battle and think on your feet to survive. There are different types, some which explode in your face, others which charge at you, and some that stay at a safe distance and snipe away... with rockets. The few boss fights are challenging and old-school as well, involving glowing weak points and waves of minions, but when you learn their pattern you feel unstoppable. For the most part, combat is challenging, but fair; if you fail, you know it's your fault. On the other hand, the little guys are a lot more troublesome because they love to hide and ambush you, get right in your face and when they die, they cause damage if you're that close. Every single room in the game is filled with destructible objects which either explode or cause electrical damage, so you can imagine that one stray bullet, even from the enemy, often sets off a chain reaction of things exploding in your face. At times like these, the game feels unfair. Dodging or jumping doesn't always save you, enemies sneak up behind you with ease and it's easy to get trapped in a corner, so many situations turn into trial-and-error. Some enemies love to hang out at a distance behind cover and are difficult to destroy with anything but one or two weapon types which you can't even buy until later on. Rockets and mortar shells constantly fly at you and FPS logic tells you that if you're behind cover or sprint several feet away from its impact, you'll be safe... but not always. Enemy projectiles' splash damage has a ridiculous reach.

Your own weapons are still formidable, however. You get only two (with separate ammo types), but a whopping five firemodes apiece, each of which is designed for certain situations. You have the minigun, grenade launcher, rocket launcher, railgun, shotgun, proximity mines and my favorite, the smartgun which detects enemies and shoots through walls. You can also upgrade your weapons, health and armor through seamless first-person terminals, using experience you collect from combat and finding secret areas. But even if you fully upgrade your health and shield, it's not by much; Hard Reset doesn't hold your hand and the only assurance you have is frequent checkpoints and no game over. The only guidance you have is a vague objective and the occasional voiceover communication.

Speaking of which... the voice acting is awful. With the exception of one guy, it's just ingenuine and unenthusiastic. The music is also total crap, consisting of the occasional ambient pad and a bunch of random futuristic drilling noises, like a robot dentist's equipment. Apparently, the composer didn't care either, but at least it lets you know when you're entering a fight. There is actual music when action begins, but it's your average, generic attempt at sounding futuristic: lots of synths, breakbeats and the occasional guitar. Completely forgettable at best, grating at its worst.
The sound on the other hand, is great. Every little object you bump into sounds real, the sound of robots exploding into piles of scrap is satisfying and the weapons sound appropriately futuristic and cool.

The visuals are gorgeous. That should be obvious considering it's on the Unreal 3 engine, but the environments look amazing. The dystopian city of Bezoar stretches out around and above you, massive and intricate, triggering memories of Blade Runner or Hong Kong from Deus Ex: Human Revolution. So many scenes in this game deserve that you stop and just take a  look around. It's such a shame then, that this game is fast-moving and direct by its very nature. The models and textures are beautiful; things that anyone would be proud to put on their resume. Most props fully utilize the Havok physics engine and behave realistically, never once glitching for me. The layout of certain objects in certain places doesn't always make sense, but it's still cool to see things fly everywhere in the heat of battle.

I'll mention the story last because it's not important. In fact, it's barely there at all. In between levels, what little plot there is is expounded through cutscenes which look suspiciously like rough draft cinematics; you know, a comic book of moving sketches designed to give an idea of what the finished, pre-rendered cutscene will look like. But there's a difference between stylish, comic book cutscenes (see: Beneath a Steel Sky, Max Payne 2) and a rough draft someone never finished. Anyway, the story has something to do with a network of digital personalities, the big, faceless, evil corporation that controls it and robots that want it. Very little is ever explained, leading to more confusion. But again, it's not that important because when you're playing, you only get a vague objective to strive for and the occasional voiceover telling you what to do next, very little context or exposition. And that's another thing: The environments, visuals and sound design make me want to explore this world, understand it, spend some time in it, but that just ain't gonna happen.

It's a very short game too; if you spend no time collecting secrets and are better at staying alive than me (which is likely), you'll blaze through it in no time and wonder what the Hell just happened. The Exile DLC is included, although it's more like almost half the game the developers didn't have time to finish before release". Seriously

reviewText: I did want to like this game.  It did a lot right.  The cyberpunk aesthetic and Road Hog engine look fantastic, and the weapon variety is great and uniquely set up.  Sadly, that's where the praise ends.  Hard Reset suffers from spongy combat, a complete inability to dodge attacks, and some rather frustrating artificial difficulty.  At the end of the day, you just probably won't have fun with the game.  You can only get so many downright unfair deaths before you have to throw in the towel.\n\nThankfully, FWH learned their mistakes with Shadow Warrior.  You can dodge enemies, they'll stagger if you hit them hard enough, you have moves that can knock them over or stun them, and overall SW was a similar game that just worked properly.  With FWH going back to apply their Shadow Warrior successes to rebalance this game in the Redux version, I'd say you should just skip to there.  The original game just isn't worth your time, and for anyone who owns either this version or Shadow Warrior, you can buy the Redux of Hard Reset for a mere $3.  This version has more reasonable combat, dodging, and a laser katana, an easy recommendation as it's exactly what this game needed to work.

reviewText: Fun, but frustrating at times-Hard Reset is a cyber punk first person shooter set in the city of Bezoar. The year is 2436. You are one of the last remaining humans on earth. Machines, big and small are now controlling vast areas of what became the barrens. You must now fight your way through different levels in the game to complete your missions. In the game, you will have weapons to fight with, a chance to upgrade all weapons, find secrets(they are scattered all over the levels). This may sound easy, but trust me, at times, it isn't. There are machines in the game(Robots) who can and do charge at you, Little flying Robots with sawblades who come at you, among a few, and as the game progresses, it gets progressively harder, even starting on the easy levels. overall, this game is fun, but as the title of my review states, it can be frustrating at times. Very frustrating as you get deeper into it. Only two complaints about this game:1. No Crouch mode. 2. No Cheats. If your into Cyber Punk Shooters, then this one may be worth checking out.

reviewText: This game was far better then expected. If you want, play the demo and get a feel for yourself. The game has some similarities to the Serious Sam and Painkiller type games. The only difference is the universe and the enemies. It's set in a cyberpunk universe with some pretty good visuals. What sets this apart are the guns and the enemies. Instead of having 15 different guns, you have 2 guns that have alternate modes that link to the 15 other weapons which makes for a different fighting experience. Also your enemies are 100% robots so figuring out how they die is tricky. Normal fleshy enemies you can figure out just how much will kill them. Not so here. Heck, there are a few enemies that are almost impossable to figure out how much will destroy them until they blow. Plus the boss fights for this game are superb and the dlcs they release are free! Those are some recipes for success in my book. The game isn't extremely long but it isn't short either. For a game I spent a few bucks on, this was a real winner in my mind. Play the demo to get your own feel then buy a fantastic no cover shooter game, you won't be disapointed.

reviewText:
Awesome indie shooter. Plenty of particle effects and explosions. Runs my graphics card extremely hard so make sure you have a good computer setup before you try to turn up the graphics on this bad boy. Pros:

Old School, Healthpack picking up, no crouching shooter
Customizable Character and Upgrade Tree
Great Graphics
Solid, Clean Gameplay

Cons:

Old School, Healthpack picking up, no crouching shooter
Fairly linear level design
Repetative Environments

If you want to blast some stuff and want a graphically updated version of the shooters you've loved in the past grab this indie gem. B+

Overall rating: 8/10

First off, I just want to say that this game is absolutely beautiful. The neon-lit cyberpunk aesthetic really gave me a 'Blade Runner' vibe, and on ultra settings, it just looks stunning. The music always fits the scene and helps get the blood pumping, whilst the voice acting is average, but doesn't distract from the game

The actual gameplay is good, although towards the end, the game does degenerate into an arena-style shooter with waves after waves of enemies running towards you. However, the gunplay is fun and I never found myself getting bored. I just wish there was some more variety in the levels.

reviewText:
If you like FPS's (Dynamic/destructive scenery) with a little bit of thinking required, then this game is obscure gem, for anyone who likes comparisons, if you like(d) Bullet Storm, you'll like this!
(Overall 8.625/10)

The graphics (8.5/10):
Are very nice - nothing ultra amazing, but extremely well done, nice lighting, etc.

The sound (8.5/10):
Is very clear (not too much goin on, all the time), in keeping with the theme and well thought out, directional sound is well positioned. Music offers nice dymanics, where required.

The general 'feel' of the aiming  (9.5/10):
Is about 'right' - There is a lttle bullet deviation and spread, but not so much that you cannot hit anything unless it is 2 foot from you.

The cut sceens (8/10):
Are in a comic book style and the voice overs potray the emotion required, although (as with all titles of this style) are a bit hammy/cheesy, but I think this fits in with the overall theme of the game.

As this game does not spoon feed you the path and objectives with big arrows flashing above x, y or z. You do need to pay some attentiopn to what is actaully being asked and this encourages exploration and testing different destructive options with the scenery.

All in all, I am extremely pleased with this title and will endeavour to look for more by this software team - The latest remake/reboot of Shadow Warrior being the obvious next title to explore.

reviewText:
Hard Reset is very much like Painkiller or Serious Sam.  You have to manage plowing through waves of little bad guys in each area, while keeping your ammo and heal counts up, especially for when the big guys come out.  It's like those other modern shooters in terms of the level design being very linear and corridor-like, except that the combat is actually fun thanks to some clever weapon design.  There's also loads of completely inexcusable invisible walls that you will never get used to, both in secret hunting, and in trying to deftly maneuver in combat.

The visuals are reminiscent of a shooter that's several years older, but they get the job done in terms of providing an appropriate and unique atmosphere.  I find the comic-book style cutscenes to be both moderately well executed and out of place.  The writing is bad, the story is pointless, but killing things in a cyberpunk city is fun.

Honestly, I prefer Hard Reset to Painkiller and Serious Sam.  I prefer the level-up choices that the game offers me and it provides some choice-driven context to a genre (corridor shooter) that generally  has none.

reviewText:
It feels like I have been dropped into the 2000AD comic series. It's like being right there.

I seriously love the way this game looks. The city graphics are second to none for me, but I haven't played all the most modern games. Combat is great, if a bit tough at times. Combat with robots is extreme sublime. Although slightly short it has become one of my favourite gaming experiences. I played the demo a few times. I have played though on hard difficulty twice. My second play through took 12 hours including DLC levels. My first play through took longer partly because I was gawping at all the graphics.

Really though I feel I am there in the comics, like they came to life, and I am in it. Incredible feeling. Awesome engine and concept.

Hardware for max settings;
A good i5 and GTX650 Ti will keep frames rates above 25fps with settings maxed. It will be well over 25fps in many places. This type of hardware will keep it smooth in the most heated battles.

Hint:
Make the shotgun your first upgrade. It is a game changer.
Take the railgun and RPG upgrades soon, as again they are game changers. (The railgun is the only long range fast weapon. Other weapon types I did not even try.)
I used these weapons and all the combat gear upgrades.

Minor bad point:
One or two of the checkpoints are a bit far apart.
My fight with the first boss nearly stopped me playing, but youtube showed me I had to use different weapons.
One particular secret I can not work out. I could look it up online.
Shame it is slightly short, even with the free DLC. I just haven't had enough for such a superb concept game. (It takes longer than Crysis to play though.)

reviewText:
Hard Reset is a great game to spend time and beat. It has loads of secrets and achievements for completionists. Very fluid combat system as well, for the FPS-junkies. Good story if you want to follow the plot.
The weapons are basic when you start out- A kinetic rifle and an energy rifle. Both have 4 different uprades (same with your defensive items) and 3 sub-upgrades, so each playthrough can be a little different from the last.
Every level has a lot of enemies which always makes you feel like 'OH SH!T' every time you see a large group, and they always know you're there, so no super-sneaky type stuff either.
*tip* invest in the railgun/shotgun early on to help out with tougher enemies.

The only complaint is that the game is far too short, even with the DLC.
Not to mention they left the ending in a cliffhanger type deal, leaving the player to imagine what happens next.

But overall, 8.9/10

reviewText:
A very unbalanced game design that will often have you killed because you were kicked in a corner and unable to move away, or enemies will spawn behind you without warning, and the enemies are boring. But the weapons are really fun.

To be a bit more honest, that game suffers from 4 very bad problems :
- the enemies are all faster than you. You can sprint to bypass that peculiar issue, but given that you can only sprint forward, that the levels are quite small, and that you can't shoot while sprinting, it's basically useless,
- the levels are very beautiful, but sadly, they are filled with invisible walls. Graphically, you're moving in a futuristic town, but in fact, the game could just be a bunch of rooms and corridors,
- I do not know how explosions are programmed, but a wall will never protect you from an explosion. I did the test of hiding myself in a container (three walls and a roofs) and yet I still took damage from explosions,
- and the most annoying problem : that blur each time you get hit. No matter if that missile took 75HP or one, your screen will get blurred, making it impossible to see how your health is. And if you're ganged up on by enemies, you're done for. They'll constantly knockback you and kill you extremely quickly.

Otherwise, enemies are fairly challenging, with a very decent tracking (that's a nice way to say you'll fail almost every evade and get charged by that giant angry robot")
date: but your weapons are diverse and powerful enough to not turn the fights into a chore."

reviewText:
Hard Reset Exteneded Edition (otherwise known as the finished product) is a sci-fi first-person shooter developed by Flying Wild Hog; a team consisting of a few members who worked on Painkiller. This was their first published title and you can tell that some aspects of the game were experimental or not fleshed out as well as it could be.

Gameplay : The primary focus of the game is its gunplay. The game revolves around a kinetic weapon and a energy weapon with each having five separate forms and each form having an alternate fire function. The kinetic weapon functions as a rifle, a shotgun, a grenade launcher, a rocket launcher, and a proximity mine deployer. The energy weapon functions as a rapid-fire pulse rifle, a close-range lightning arc, an EMP grenade launcher, a sniper rifle, and a homing weapon. The weapon models look great, but it can get confusing in-game knowing which weapon is in what mode which can lead to some unwanted splash damage. Enemy variety is sub-par up until the later levels, where it upgrades to servicable. Another problem is that the enemy models, all of them robots, don't stand out against the environment often enough. The health system involves a non-regenerating health bar which can be replenished with medkits (some enemies can drop small medkits upon their defeat) and a shield system that regenerates when you're not under fire. The game also boasts a light RPG element where you spend currency to upgrade your armaments as well as your combat suit. There are also environmental hazards littered throughout the levels which you can employ to take out enemies. The few bosses in the game are a delightful distraction from the masses of robots you destroy as you progress through the stages. On a sidenote, the in-game interface is cleverly done since everything in the game is mouse-driven. Overall, the gameplay can keep you engaged through completion.

The story is easily the weakest part of the game, with voice actors phoning it in and the plot convulutes itself to a lackluster ending. The level design is cyberpunkish buildings through two-thirds of the game until it changes it up with a more varied environment at the final third. However, the design is also very linear with secrets" that can be found by turning the other corner before going down the beaten path. Technically
date: the game runs smoothly with a benchmark inside the extras menu of the game.\n\nI would recommend picking this one up if you want a shooter that doesn't adhere to the modern military standard. At time of writing
recommended: the developers have made plans to release a Hard Reset Redux Edition which would upgrade the game engine to its latest version

reviewText:
Pretty good FPS! Old-school in the sense of Painkiller and Serious Sam, rather than DOOM and DukeNukem.

The level design isn't as interesting as the latter, but the game still has room for a few secrets for you to uncover. Each weapon is unique, with various uses, although the slow upgrade system doesn't encourage experimentation with the weapons (it's balanced for you to have 80-85% of the upgrades by the end of the game).
Still, even though it may take a while, each weapon is pretty satisfying.

Wave uponh wave of enemies. The big problem is how resilient they are to damage. Even a rocket launcher is rather inneffective... Then again, I played on Hard mode. It's... really hard. Sometimes frustrating, putting high damage enemies with you into very small spaces.

But, despite that big flaw, the game is still a hell of a lot of fun!

Visually, it's nothing short of impressive, with a huge, cyberpunk city. The lighting system is pretty good as well.

Then, there's the physic's system. It's a big part of what makes this game awesome to play! Everything explodes and breaks apart, and you can basically shoot everything long after they're dead. It gets a bit too resource intensive, but it's worth it.

The levels are a bit too long to my taste (usually 40minutes +), seeing how much you die. Checkpoints are really unforgiving as well, with the game lacking a quicksave" feature.

But hey

reviewText:
Red barrels - the videogame.

Eh... I picked it up for 2 euros, so I can recommend it at the pricetag, but honestly, compared to Shadow Warrior (2013) this game is not very good for the most part.

Especially if you get the wrong upgrades. Some weapons are useless even after you get the upgrades (looking at you, assault rifle). It wasn't until I painfully played through half the game when I realized, that the way to go here is to permastun enemies. Get all the CC upgrades, use RPG and railgun for dealing big damage, shotgun for wave clearing.

There's not a lot of enemy variety either. You got the little annoying ones, you've got the big charging ones, the rocket spammers and the scarabs. They do have a varied look based on how much armor they are packing, but at the end of the day they have the same abilities with a different paintjob.

The enemies are bullet sponges as well. UNLESS, you use the red barrels to kill them. The game puts a lot of emphasis on that, rather than the gunplay, which is a shame. 1-2 red barrels can kill the bigges enemies, but if you try to do the same with your guns, it will take a long while. There are plenty of red barrels in the first few chapters, but later they get more scarce and therefore the fights are needlessly prolonged, because you are waiting for the day the spongy enemies will finally die.

I also noticed a lot of inconsistency in this game. Sometimes the little sawblade enemies deal only like 20 damage, sometimes up to 80. I have no idea wtf going on whatsoever. Is it because of my shield? But even if my shield are full, I still lose HP when I'm hit. Is it proportional? Is the damage only halved? Are shields only protecting from ranged attacks? I have no idea what's going on.

This game does one thing pretty damn well though, and that's the boss fights. The boss fights with Atlas and the Overseer from the Exile DLC are particularly well done. I really liked how I had to get the Overseer to suck in the barrels. That was a bit creative and unusual. Really good boss fight, that one. The parts of the game between the boss fights are really not enjoyable though.

In conclusion you can very much tell that this is the studios 1st game. It was an experiment. I'd say play Shadow Warrior instead, if you haven't played already. That's a much much more polished version of all the ideas this game experimented with and therefore a thoroughly enjoyable game. Get this game only at a huge discount and only if you are very bored.

reviewText:
Originally, i didn't like Hard Reset, and stopped after less than an hour.
I didn't understand why there were only two weapons, nor why there was a separate command to select each. I didn't understand why i was moving from area to area, killing hordes of robots and i didn't understand why i was so bad at it...

For the next few months, Hard Reset sat in my games list, with just 1 achievement, mocking me.

Recently, Iâ€™ve been aiming for perfect games (a 100% achievement score), trying to increase my average completion rate. So with only one achievement, the time came back around to re-install Hard Reset, and try to bump my rating back up.

After it was re-installed, i had the option to continue my last save, so i clicked the resume button, and in i went. Still on the first level, i continued my desperate struggle against the machines, and again, trying to make sense of the area to area robot horde killing gameplay.

This is probably the point that changed the game for me. My next challenge was to fight one of the bigger robots (the kind that charges at you), and i hadnâ€™t realised that i was being awarded points for destroying the enemies, as well as collecting the orange pickups. â€œA new upgrade is availableâ€ flashed on the screen, and having already found an upgrade terminal, i quickly found the next one. I took a grenade launcher on the CLG Firearm.

The controls need explaining. Itâ€™s Q to select the CLG Firearm and E to select the NRG Weapon, after you add a new function to each one, youâ€™ll be able to select that function with a number, so for example, i would have the CLG firearm selected with Q, then to select the normal machine gun mode, you would press 1, the shotgun function would be 2, and for my newly acquired grenade launcher, i would have to press 3.

Now i had an incentive to carry on. To become more powerful, i would have to continue, and the achievements had already started popping up in the corner. Then, i think i started to like Hard Reset, i was looking forward to getting past the next section, getting my next upgrade, and finding all of those delicious secrets.


Currently, iâ€™m playing it through on hard mode, which involves many re-tries. Every section is a case of trial and error. You go in, get horded, die, then retry, positioning yourself in a better place, to get past the first spawn. The second and third hordes of the area, will no doubt kill you again and again. Forcing you to retry, each time, remembering where the enemies come from, and to be ready, bottlenecking them with the scenery, and using the environment to your advantage.

Hard Reset would probably describe itself as an environmental shooter, as half of the scenery is either explosive, or has electronics wired so badly that a light kick would force it to short out and electrocute everything in a 2 metre radius.

So, my advice would be, to sit it out, play the first level to the end, try not to give up immediately. I understand now, why there are only two weapons, and generally how the game is compiled together giving the player individual challenges, and i understand why i struggled at first.

The only thing i donâ€™t understand, is why i like this game so much, now.

reviewText:
For guys craving a twitch shooter akin to Serious Sam and 3D versions of old school Duke Nukem and Shadow Warrior, this would be your jam. But for casual players looking to dabble in everything or just plain like shooters, there's so much wrong with it. There are no truly innovative ways to kill AI, some just soak up more bullets than others. I don't quite understand it. The story in itself is warped and beyond fixing. The characters are bland extrapolations of stereotypes in the countless games you've played before or movies you've seen. Objectives can be mundane and keep you confused as to what you're all really playing this game for aside from its stellar level and weapon upgrade design. It also relies on the gimmick of red barrels, which wears off after the first 2 levels.

They fixed some of the issues (a CQC weapon & dodge mechanics) in the redux, and I would recommend that if you haven't gotten the Redux yet.

Is it worth it after you upgrade it? No. The core gameplay and mechanics will be just as boring the first time you played it. You just get to dodge charges and get a sword that's only useful on Easy difficulty. It doesn't have a skill tree, so it feels like they just threw it in there. That, and the graphics look identical to its 2011 counterpark. Total cash grab.

reviewText:
Surprisingly decent fast paced old school fps in the mold of Doom/Unreal etc. The game has some decent visuals and variation in its environment throughtout the game so it doesnt get boring. With the Exile DLC you get more than enough time to upgrade most of the weapons throughout your first playthrough aswell albeit it can feel a bit tedious by the time you get to the DLC. Its got some nice visuals and cyberpunk style thats sadly accompanied with hand drawn/Comic book style cutscenes that doesnt complement the main games visual style like say the Max Payne games. On top of that the 2 main characters are neither likeable nor interesting to listen to which leaves the cutscenes and story as a flat encouragement for the upcoming levels. Thankfully the game is addictive enough to keep you going.

The game is approx. 7-9 hours long and manages to keep you interested throughout with the varied weapons and level design albeit the enemy encounters generally feel a tad too much of the same. The small enemy robots running around to warn you that a encounter is about to happen gets really old quick though and they seem to overuse it too much throughout it.

Some of the negative aspects of the game has to be the very limited enemy variations. Theres like 3-4 sized enemy types with 2-3 variations each. Meaning theres about 8-10 enemies in total with the DLC and a couple bosses thrown into the mix.

The gameplay itself feels a bit too much of the same, you can easily see when coming into a new area that youre gonna spam alot of enemies, which means youll often find yourself picking out the 2 weapons youre going to use the most in  the encounter and thats pretty much how every fight goes in the game added with the mix of using the exploding barrels and electric barries in the environment as support..

The visuals are decent everything close to you looks pretty nicely detailed overall but far objects like buildings really lack that extra work and detail.

The weapon system consists of 2 main weapons (1 Plasma Cannon/1 Regular Firearm/Machinegun) you can switch between, each of the 2 then has 5 individual weapons with a regular function and a secondary one (Mouse1&2 usually) you can unlock by finding EXP throughout the levels and killing enemies. The problem with this weapon system though while it looks cool at first sadly becomes a bit of a chore to use due to lack of visual difference between the 5 functions each has. For example the plasma cannon pretty much only changes in how big the bulb is on when switching between them, it means you will often find yourself using the wrong weapon in fights that are usually short and fast paced with alot of enemies on screen. You will quickly find 2 favourites you will mostly stick to throughout the game due to this design choice.

Id recommend the game due to the satisfaction you get of scrapping robots, its a nice length for the type of game and the weapons and enemies are generally fun to use & kill. Its a decent game to have as a FPS backup on your steam account when youve run out of the top tier FPS games and at some point need a new FPS fix. Its mediocre as hell but its good at being it.

6.5/10

reviewText:
Hard Reset is an FPS in the vein of the genesis of FPS. Combat is quick and based around movement and lots of guns rather than cover and patience.

Unfortunately it feels a bit clunky, you have a jump but it's basically useless and there is no crouch. Sprinting is fairly limited and the screen distorts so much you can't really see anything, leading you to often rush headlong into enemies. As expected you can unlock a plethora of weapons to help you along the way. There are 10 guns in total, each with an alternate fire. The weapons are split into two classes, one firing physical ammo the other firing energy. While I didn't use a number of the weapons or firing modes it was enjoyable to work out the best gun/mode combos for each enemy type. The weapons feel decent and some are pretty fun to use, but the swap time is agonizingly slow.

The level design is that of a corridor shooter but the fact that it is essentially linear is a bit of departure from the days of yore. There are plenty of secrets tucked into corners or behind destructible walls but it's not like you'll be exploring vast open levels to find them. The world is heavily cyberpunk and takes place almost entirely at night in the rain. It looks pretty good for what I suspect is a pretty minimal budget. It's an interesting world that is severely undersold by the story. Mostly told between levels by clunky animated, poorly voice acted cut scenes" done in a graphic novel style
date: the story is underdeveloped and poorly explained. I wanted to to care about the story and the world but I just couldn't get drawn in. It just feels like there was supposed to be so much more.\n\nThe included DLC
recommended:
Exile (previously Path to Exile or Extended Edition) is essentially more if the same. There are a couple new enemy types but one of the guns completely removes them as a threat. Partly through Exile I realized I was just grinding and going through the paces.

In the end Hard Reset is just a bit shallow. The potential is there for a much more engaging experience but it just doesn't deliver. If you're a fan of circle strafing this is probably a must have but for generalists or people looking for a deeper cyberpunk world this is a bargain bin/bundle pick up.

reviewText: Woefully underrated, Hard Reset could be considered a cyberpunk version of Painkiller. While not as fluid as Painkiller, the combat in HR is still enjoyable. Environmental kills are plentiful, the enemies have unique visual styles, the graphics are pretty, and the weapons are fairly cool.\nThe story is forgettable; I've played through HR twice and still don't know what it was about. Which is fine because the combat is what kept me entertained. The levels are confusing at times, and the art style sometimes obscures the route forward. But, at the same time the art style is pretty enough that taking time to check stuff out can be a nice break from the combat.\nOverall, Hard Reset is great for people who enjoy run and gun action, but may not appeal to many others. It can seem difficult at times, but if you're resourceful, you'll usually find a way to use the environment to your advantage.

reviewText: Beep-boop-beep-boop-BOOOM!!! Great graphics. Cool weapons. Terrible voice acting. Not a bad shooter overall. I will admit that I had to tone it down to 'easy' just to get halfway through it. Ever wish you could play Quake in a Blade Runner type of setting? This is the game for you.\nAfter completing the entire game I can say that it's very challenging. Getting cornered by hordes of common enemies was unfortunately more damaging than the actual boss fights. While you do get a chance to lay waste to thousands of little robots utilizing a variety of weapons, there is very little variety in the enemies themselves. The only thing that really changes through the game are the weapon upgrades and environments. The included Exile DLC does introduce a few more enemies.\nOverall, it's worth playing, especially if you're itching for an improved classic shooter that won't hold your hand.

reviewText: An excellent straight-up FPS.  It has a pretty unique style, with a little bit of Painkiller mixed in.  Very skill-based and quite fun once you get used to the game mechanics.  I started out trying to play like Painkiller and that does NOT work.  Rather that using movement speed to fight enemies, the game is designed around using environmental obstacles and objects to destroy them.  And now there's a free bonus campaign!  Highly recommended, especially for the price.

reviewText:
19 hrs on record.

Pro
= LOVE THE CYBERPUNK sceneries!
- It actually has a good story ! - a game made like the old ones.
= Love the transition between loading screens - they show you cutscenes of the game and when you don't expect the overlay to be the exact beginning frame of your gameplay , it's adds a nice feel to it.
= Plethora of weapon modes to choose from: wether you like RPGs or ENERgy weapons , or shotguns, rifles, you have it there (railgun included, modes that fire through walls, EMP grenades, electricity attacks, the works !)
- nice design on futuristic cars.


- a bit of a high steep plaiying curve in Normal difficulty (if you're a versed player, enemies in the 1st round die a bit harder than expected) - it might prove a bit of a challenge for unexperienced players.

This can be a good thing. Too much 5 minute bullet time events present in game these days and 12 quick-time events for the devs to take you by the hand and finish the game for you while you duck behind chest-high walls 90% of the time...


Cons
- SOundtrack could have been better. It's quite poor actually. Jesper Kyd should have been hired for this (he also did MDK2 soundtrack, HItman, Assassin's Creed) ; heck , even I am into music production and I have some unreleased â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ better than what's in this one's soundtrack.
- enemies need more variety - 90% of them come towards you for melee; few ranged ones.
- too much motion blur (i hate it) when sprinting + FOV to +200 while doing so is ridiculous.... I'm not running with 200mph FFS!!

If you know ANACHRONOX , this game will give you a taste of the 2000's ;

reviewText:
Mix Bladerunner with Quake 3 and you have Hard Reset. No multiplayer, no co-op option - just an out-and-out gun blazing FPS of killing multiple foes as quickly as possible.

I very, very rarely say this - but Hard Reset is simply too difficult for its own good. The clue should be in the title - and that's when the game is set to Normal. Your arsenal of weapons is woefully underpowered (even, with upgrades too) and the opposing enemies are super-accurate - even over distance.

FPS Gods will no doubt blitz through level after level without dying 4 or 5 times like I usually do. But for mainstream gamers - be warned. It will test the limits of your patience! :)

That said, it is a good looking game and enjoyable too when you've had enough of online FPSs for a while.

7/10

reviewText:
Hard Reset is a FPS creation in the style of the old school shooter.

The game offers an interesting take on guns, and while not perfect, they do a lot to mixup the play-styles throughout the 8 hours on offer here (including dlc). The process of unlocking upgrades leaves you with something new and interesting to try until the very end. The proximity grenades that you can detonate whenever you want with the second mouse button was a personal favorite. Flinging a proximity mine over a group of enemies then detonating it just as it sailed above their heads (sending them flying in all directions) never got old.

On the negative side the levels are quite linear. Throughout the game you find yourself either in a narrow corridor, a wide corridor, or a big box with scattered obstacles. The environments look nice, but I feel like a big opportunity was lost by keeping it so linear. It's pretty evident what gun works best where, so a lot of the time you feel quite railroaded in tactics.

That said the enemies have been well designed with the linear levels in mind and certainly keep you on your toes without ever feeling unfair. They do tend to the charging straight at you" variety
recommended: reduces your tactics quite a bit. To somewhat make up for that there's a great deal of destructible objects in the environment which can hinder your enemies in different ways.\n\nThe game prides itself on its 'old-school' style. But though the weapons feel right the player control doesn't. Compared to the classics the movement speed is slow

And the less said about the plot the better.

So If you're in the mood for a short

reviewText:
Hard Reset is a slick, unforgiving FPS that feels ripped from the genre's roots. Were it not for the updated graphics and more responsive controls, you'd swear this direct was kin to Wolfenstein, Doom, and Quake. Coat it in a lusciously dystopian cyberpunk coat of paint and you've got me by the sensitive bits; just be aware that Hard Reset is liable to kick you in those bits just as readily.

Pulling no punches, Hard Reset puts you in the shoes of Fletcher, hands you a strange energy weapon full of upgrade potential, and then starts lobbing wave after wave of robotic foes at you with little time to breathe in between. Action becomes stick-and-move most of the time as you work your way around each level, avoiding fire more than taking cover from it and taking as much advantage as you can of the environment. That environmental element was probably my favorite aspect of the game, as traditional exploding barrels are joined by things such as electrical boxes that can short out your opponents, and just natural-feeling static elements like barriers and columns that can, to some degree, help control enemy direction and flow.

Unless you've been maintaining your twitch reflexes since FPS' toddler days or you're gifted with ungodly reaction time, Hard Reset is likely to kick you around quite a bit at first. Stick with it, though, and explore your upgrade options for your weapon. Once you've gotten the feel for the game's flow and found a setup that suits your needs, things start thrumming like, well, machinery.

reviewText:
The mechanics and graphics of the game are solid, with the 2 weapon upgrade system
especially notable.

However, this game often fails to let you go where you want to go, with no jumping while sprinting, and randomly placed invisible walls preventing you from deviating from the desired path, including to some secrets where you have to progress further before you're meant to come backtrack and then find them on that walk through.

It also is unnecessarily punishing, with trips into dead ends for secrets (upgrade points) spawning waves from nowhere that mob the culdesac, with doors randomly locking behind you with a wave bearing down so you have nowhere to hide, and sometimes with enemies spawning in areas with no cover so you just have to pray your way through.

I was playing on the hardest setting, so my fragility was probably enhanced, but little to no cover in some areas and the inability to jump things that you should be able to jump over, just ruined the game for me.

reviewText:
Got this cheap in a sale. For that price, it's a decent enough game, but there are a few things holding it back. Some of the times I died, I wasn't sure what killed me, or you could get jammed into the corner by enemies and then meleed quickly to death. In some places you're deliberately shoved into tiny areas with large monsters... which I tend to find irritating rather than a fair challenge.

The upgrade system was kinda fun, though I'm not sure what the point of having two guns was - in this game 1 gun can have 5 functions, which are all the different weapon types you need. Seems a better prospect to use just one of the gun types rather than both... I stuck with the mechanical gun throughout. Played through on Normal mode... though if the harder modes requrie more ammo, you may want to have rocket launcher/shotgun/machinegun combo on both. The enemy HUD upgrade I think should've been a default feature rather than an upgrade tbh.

The game is pretty short, but if you're buying this in a sale, the length doesn't matter as much... but the ending is definitely cliffhanger'd, which was disapponting for me. I think they could have written a bit more on it, even if they left a challenge open at the end of it, just to add to the sense of completion. In general, the plot could do with a little more beefing up, just to get a better sense of the world and what the heck is going on. You're not going to find a groundbreaking plot here, but I don't think it's the kind of game that needs a unique plot.

As far as technical problems go, I didn't experience any bugs ingame that I noticed, but I did have the game crash twice, and unsure why. Did knock my progress back a bit, but not too far. Played the game on ultra, got the odd bit of slowdown when things were really busy (2-3 times), but definitely playable on my rig... so I regard it as a decently performing game.

In general, I wouldn't recommend this game to people, but if you're a big fan of shooters, you may have some fun with it.
