reviewText:
Hard Reset is a very, how do I put it, interesting unique take on the genre of shooters. It seems more like the outset of a butterfly. Looks wonderous on the outside, extremely vague and odd on the inside. Starting off, the game tells me the controls of the game. I don't mind that at all. Does that well so far. I also thought it was pretty innovative how if you hover your cursor over a nearby screen it starts up the little video for you so if you want to watch it you don't have to wait for it to start all over again, just move your cursor away if you are not interested.

Then I get to what appears to be a larger robot than all the other little ones that come in clusters. These appear to be bullet sponges but I thought I had to have a special way of taking them down with the alternate plasma weapon I had. Of course not knowing this I tried everything but the bullet spongey method and frustrated myself unnecessarily. Finally, it worked sinking mass amounts of bullets into it and got it killed. It told me how to do everything else but not how to handle the big boys? I was so confused I thought I broke the game.

Also the game has a VERY obscure way of explaining things. Some things it will show you directly, others it will just say figure it out yourself. It seems like this game wants to be too many things for a 3000ish MB type game and I am actually quite disappointed. To be fair I did not expect much from a game this size its just that if you plan to make a tutorial for your game, explain things properly. Certain actions like jumping are clearly explained. Other very vague things like pickups and even when you first visit the upgrading station. It's incredible how much work was put into this but not enough work to explain what all this is. I was stunned. Not to mention that you don't have enough to DO anything when you get there. You figure at least they would give you enough currency to start off with to demonstrate how the buying process works but that never came into play.

Long story short: I do not recommend buying this game. A lot of things are bullet spongey, other things are very obscure and you have no idea what to do, a lot of things are just blindly there being picked up and you don't know if you should pick it up or not. If you cannot make a decent tutorial, how are you gonna pull in your playerbase? If I am offput on how a tutorial explains things, there's a problem with your game.
A more fleshed out tutorial needs to be made for the customers. If you are planning to innovate the FPS genre, might wanna flesh out how your game works first so people aren't wandering around blindly, asking themselves What is this? What's this? What's that thing? What do I do? I'm so confused!"

Sorry guys I do not recommend this as a purchase. That's just who I am."

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but it has glaring flaws. The checkpoint system is garbage, this is a PC game not a console game. Twice I've had to re-load the game because I've been stuck in the scenery hunting for upgrades only to be forced to clear out an area of enemies again.

Which brings up another issue, if you do decide to get this game avoid the shotgun. I saved up upgrades and upgraded it all the way, then hit a check point, sealing my fate. The shotgun in this game has no impact on enemies, so you wait for them to get close to use it, shoot them, and even the 2 foot tall enemies will walk right through the blast and hit you anyway. And it does little to no damage on enemies.

The only way you can survive the higher difficulties on here as far as I can tell is to constantly kite enemies around near things that can explode (which is nearly everything, strangely enough) because none of the weapons seem to do an acceptable amount of damage to enemies.

Another problem slightly related to getting stuck in the scenery I've encountered is the fact that you're always dodging things flying around and being pushed into a corner because an enemy is pushing a 10 foot by 10 foot crate around in front of it. It makes for a very annoying experience.

With a little more polish this game has the potential to be great, but in its current state I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
I tried to like this game.  I really did.  I booted this game up on three seperate occasions in an attempt to get through it, but why bother if it's not fun?  The whole ordeal was a slog through slow paced shooting sections.  There is obviously an attention to to detail here, but the core elements of the game are just fundamentally broken.  The story is delivered through minimal character voice overs during gameplay and short comic strip-like segments between loading screens.  The voice is acting is...decent, and the comic style of the cutscenes is interesting.  But beyond an interesting comic style and a neo-future cyberpunk setting, this game falls flat.

There is an attempt at interest, but the cyberpunk setting is washed out by a spew of browns and grays in a variety of dark and blue-tinted areas.  The setting never really feels different between two locations: street level and underground.  The enemies are all bulletsponges and their design are both from an aesthetic standpoint, and a gameplay standpoint, uninspired.  Every enemy is a one trick pony, repeatedly attempting to kill with it's one attack mechanism.  For most enemies, you simply dodge while holding down the trigger until either they blow up, or you run out of ammo.  The topic of dodging leads me to my next point that the level design is awful.  I would expect this kind of design from a student project, not a full release game.  The areas are excessively linear with obvious tells for every single ambush of enemy robots.  Environmental hazards play a large role in the combat, but everything is incredibly played out.  If there is going to be a wave of enemies to ambush you, there will also be a series of explosive barrels or electrical spouting conduits to fry them up.  Most enemy encounters are simply there to pad the experience.  Many times enemies seemed to just appear in an area because the game said so.  Most combat was either myself against a large charging enemy in an open area, or myself against many small enemies in a closed area.  When you are required to dodge many small enemies in a closed off corridor like area with minimal movement, it's not fun, it's not a challenge, it's frustrating.  In one instance, an ambush blew through a wall, but upon inspection of their entrance point, it was a closed concrete block in a hole.

You only get two weapons in the game.  Each one has it's own twist, and the weapon variety is accomplished through allowing upgrades for each of these two weapons.  Through the usage of upgrades, your bullet based weapon and your plasma based weapon can each turn into 4 other weapons, totalling 10 different guns.  However, these guns feels the same.  None of your attacks seem to have presence.  Accuracy is abyssmal, and when combined with the fact that all enemies have massive amounts of health (or you simply don't deal any damage) any combat interacting is simply tedious.

The movement is a joke too.  For a game that so heavily relies on dodging telegraphed enemy attacks, movement is stagnant and stale feeling.  Your characters jaunts around at a slightly sluggish speed.  You have the ability to sprint - if I could even call it that - but it really just makes your character move slightly faster for only a few seconds and makes your screen and HUD shake a lot.  The jump is floaty, as if your character lacks weight, and you also can't jump while sprinting.  There was a speed puzzle where a lift needed to be activated by a button across the room.  You then had to run down a staircase and across the room before it went back up.  With the sluggish controls, it was tedious and took multiple attempts before realizing that to get there faster, I should not sprint, so that I could jump into the lift as it was going up.

There are definitely some cool concepts here.  Floating UIs for upgrade panels and actual interaction screens for devices in the game are interesting and function very well.  The visuals themselves are very good.  Everything is for the most part impressively rendered and the visual effects are nice to look at.  But the art style, the sluggish controls, unvaried weapons, and completely uninteresting and uninspired combat really sink this game.  I tried to like it, but I can't and shouldn't have to force myself to clear a game out of my backlog.

reviewText:
This game is so bad...

It tries to copy Serious Sam but in a totally BAD and annoying way. It wants you to shoot 50K enemies per level, but all of the fights/encounters lack the fun element thats been replaced by the annyoing element. Once the fighting starts, you dont really understand much thats going on on the screen, as it immediatelly fills up with a gazillion effects that would normaly add to a game, but in this case, its WAY too much and that is causing the exact opposite effect. It also almost forces you to use the environment to kill off the hordes of enemies, but because of a lack of imagination, its counter- productive and intuitive.

They tried to fill it up with everything that was good in other shooters, but ended up with a bad stew. You cant just take all the good things from other shooters (or whatever other genre) and throw them together into your game, thinking its gonna be perfect. All those elements need to have a certain sinergy and that sinergy is influenced by the creative mind of the developer where he uses various bridges to link those elements together.

I could go on for another half an hour about why this game is bad, but its one of those things that no matter how many of the flaws you mention, they are just to many to overlook or to fix thru patches or DLCs.

The only nice thing about the game is the graphics... but as Indie games have proven time and time again, you dont need Crysis/Battlefield/CoD/etc type of graphics to build an encredibly fun game.

reviewText:
The level design is just boring - you walk from one open flat arena to another, then doors close and enemy robots start spawning in the arena. The enemies aren't very varied - I remember 4 or 5 types. You cannot avoid them, cannot run away from them, cannot make them fight each other (like in Doom 1-2). Aside from robots, there are no other NPCs in the game.
Invisible walls are everywhere - you cannot jump your way to the secret area, cannot even jump on the stair railing. Why did they leave the ability to jump at all?

Maybe the problem is in false advertising - it was promoted as old-school, which it really isn't. It doesn't play anything like Doom or Duke Nukem or Quake 1-2.

But I admit, the game looks great, guns have neat effects and I like the cyberpunk setting. These things kept me from abandoning the game, but as I kept nearing the final boss, the flaws were seen clearer and clearer. The main problem is that the process of killing these endless robots is just more tedious than fun (especially on higher difficulty settings), and 90% of the gameplay time we are killing robots.

reviewText:
I like hard games, and this is definitely it. Granted, I was playing at hard difficulty, but that's the way I prefer. Now, the game has an old skool approach, you are given two customizable weapons, fairly linear maps, and aggressive enemies to kill. The graphics are nice, using a lot of effects. The game runs at max 144 Hz, which is always a bonus for fps games.

Can I recommend the game? Sadly, no. I feel the game has a habit of putting you into certain puzzle-like situations. You enter a hall, an area, or drop down from a container. The next moment you might be facing waves of enemies, in a fairly small space to move around in. In this game movement is vital, most of the time you can't just stand still and destroy everything in your path. I grew frustrated over time with these waves of enemies that usually take some amounts of punishment and the small spaces the game forces you into. It is difficult but sometimes I feel in an unfair manner. I don't mind lots of enemies, but restricting your movement is a bit cheap imo.

Still, if you can get it at a discount, and enjoy challenging fps-games, this might be for you. I personally feel it to be a bit of a chore.

reviewText: At first it looked like a promising game... the graphics look pretty good, the gunplay was decent, but little did I know that this game only has TWO weapons, in 2 hours of playing (I've completed 5 missions - the original game has 7 and 12 with the dlc, so I've finished like the half of the game) I've come across only 2 enemy types: small robots and big robots and as you probably guessed it becomes a chore before long. Hard reset is very fast-paced and doesn't give you a second to catch your breath and it sounds like a good thing but the gameplay is so freaking monotonous, downright boring and isn't versatile enough to keep you excited at all. You will simply shoot robots non-stop for 4-5 hours, don't expect anything else. The story delivery is painful, and the story itself isn't that interesting either. Oh and not to mention THE GOD-AWFUL SOUNDTRACK... In the end if you decide to play it I recommend to listen to anything but the in-game sountrack. You can give it a try only if you have nothing else to play.

reviewText:
This game had great promise, an oldschool style FPS with some modern twists, but ultimately I felt it falls short. The game is does manage to execute one or two of the oldschool elements, but after multiple levels of the same secret room and enemy popping out of a wall it really wears thin.

I started on medium difficulty but due to how long it took to actually kill the enemies I lowered it just to speed things up. The game has about 6 different types of enemies that amount to nothing more than bullet sponges. Which would be fine if the guns were any fun to fire. The upgrade system was a good idea, but you end up only using 1 or 2 of the weapons which makes the reset of the upgrades worthless in the end.

I did manage to finish the game, which says soemthing, but really I would say your time is better spent on a different FPS.

reviewText:
I bought this game in the hopes of further supporting the developers, Flying Wild Hog as I enjoyed their title that they released after this game, Shadow Warrior, however the negative reviews that I kept seeing about this game were and are correct in every regard. This game is sold as Old School but it is not, I grew up playing Wolfenstine, Doom, Doom 2, Quake and so on those were old school, this game is simply a pretender that is unable to put forth even the most BASIC of FPS action and gameplay.  If you hear or read anyone speak of this title and Doom/Wolfenstine in the same breath immediately ignore them as they clearly have never played any of the true older titles as they are nothing alike and that is not a good thing.  Flying Wild Hog used the â€œold schoolâ€ phrase as a marketing tool, it is an excuse to use that phrase to get people like me who've grown up playing the real old school shooters into thinking that this game will be ANYWHERE close to the caliber that those titles were and continue to be. Everything in those games was always paced properly, always fair; you never felt like you consistently hit a wall and it didnâ€™t feel like luck to get to the next point. This game, regardless of these â€œupgradesâ€ feels nothing but a shallow shell of what it tired to do and attempts to hype itself up in order to get unsuspecting buyers. Within 20 minutes, I knew that this game had none of what I found enjoyable in Shadow Warrior, clearly the developers learned many of their lessons from this title, as it is beyond inferior or substandard even for a basic FPS game.

So far I have gotten zero enjoyment out of the experience, the weapons, much like the ballistic weapons in SW, are liken to a toy and do almost nothing to enemies. Enemies that this game's universe has KNOWN about so therefore they should actually do more then just oh annoy them a little which would make you think that humans would have developed weapons to fight beings that are basically computers. With regards to weapon damage and how they work, there appears so far to be no real way to determine if a one weapon is favored for a particular enemy over the other. Part of this is because every single enemy in this title is a damage sponge making combat experience difficult at best let alone figuring out this gameâ€™s mechanics, if one can say that it has any. The smallest of enemies do 50 times more damage then they should to the player and take 100 times more damage then they should given how frequently they put the player into the closest of close quarters with these mostly melee driven enemies and their size. I do still see some of this gameâ€™s poisonous form spilling out into their work on SW, as the enemies hit you when you clearly put some distance between you and their attack impact point or enemies that have some kind of city sized hitbox for their attack that will hit you not matter where you are in relation to the unit. In this day and age it is absolutely inexcusable that this kind of programming and blatantly unfair gameplay would be tolerated in ANY development studio.

The character you play as seems to be made of paper, thus making enemy attacks even more deadly, dare I say you could right off the bat buy all of starting medical upgrades and STILL not have enough HP to take these unending waves and low amounts of health given. Speaking of your character, he has the lung capacity of a sick new born, he can sprint for exactly 1 meter then becomes haggard, yet we are lead to believe that he is some kind of PMC solder so one would think that he would have some kind of psychical training on top of whatever cybernetics or whatever he may have in him. This lack of stamina will constantly get you killed as enemies will swarm you almost instantly unless you sprint, even though the sprint is rather slow and it barely counts, adding to that the horrible visual effect that portrays the visual of sprinting. Unlike Shadow Warrior, you do not have the ability to dodge, which in this gameâ€™s case is a seriously negative omission because it is made by the same people the enemy types or attack types are roughly the same and need to be dodged. Your character however moves as such a slow pace on top of having almost zero stamina makes for even WALKING out of the way or trying to side step an enemyâ€™s attack nearly impossible if not inconsistent.

You my notice that I have yet to talk about the â€œstory lineâ€ I have chosen to omit that because as MANY others have talked about that aspect of the game I have really nothing more to add.  The only thing that I will add is that I agree with their sentiment, the story is miniscule it would seem as if someone saw a bunch of science fiction movies and told their 10 year old to write a script while keeping those scenes in mind.  It is confusing only because it does so little to explain anything, this includes the gameâ€™s universe, this means the characters and their interactions, this means the locations and their significance, and this means the protagonist and his goals.  All the items that are essential to a proper story and the game provide none of that.  The sad part is that there is a lot of atmosphere within this universe which is obviously taken almost directly from Blade Runner.

The checkpoint system is absolute garbage and the developers felt it necessary to steal away the gameâ€™s quick save feature which is in almost Every PC game.  Especially given this gameâ€™s insane difficulty this is a crime and there are zero reasons as to why the developers choose to take out the quick save/quick load function or why they made the checkpoints so spread out other then to give the game yet another layer of fake, artificial difficulty. I really do not know how the developers slept at night knowing they made such horrible game design choices and then had the gall to market it as an old school shooter.

I honestly should have just listened to the negative reviews of this game and just stayed playing or liking Flying Wild Hogs for making SW because now my opinion of them is soured by this experience. I wanted to support them by buying their other title but now I really am unsure if I will ever bother subjecting myself to thisâ€¦Experience. Which is a damn shame because visually itâ€™s a nice universe and a semi-possible interesting story, but it is all hampered by overly punishing gameplay mechanics, claustrophobic level design and bad mechanics, I was really hoping that the other reviewers were wrong, but I see that that was not the case. This title is not a game, or what I would consider a game, a game is supposed to be fun, an enjoyable experience that keeps you coming back, this game has failed to carry with it any of the most basic FPS ideas and put them to use, for that it fails as a game and a title.

I wanted so much to like this game, or at the very least like more then 50% of it so that I could come away with at least some fond memories of my time in game.  I even pressed forward and beat the game in order to satisfy my completionist side and to confirm for myself that there was nothing positive about this game worth remembering or noting.  Beating the entire title with its added extra content DLC (which confuses the â€œstoryâ€ even more) I feel that I have seen all that there is to see about this title and that no amount of extra time within this titleâ€™s universe will change my mind.

reviewText:
I hate to say this....

...but I cannot recommend this game. I would love to do it, because the game tries to do everything in the right way, but I simply can't, because this time it just doesn't work. It's a shame, because Flying Wild Hog did a bunch of things right. Hell, they nearly headed the perfect direction, but there are a few bad development decisions that have a significant impact in the final result.

As I don't want to give the impression that this is an awful game or anything like that, I will start telling what does this game do right, because it does a couple of things right.

This game is an amazingly beautiful game. It invites to just stop and look at everything. Graphical fidelity is great (really impressive for an Indie tittle), artistic design is UNBELIEVABLE, and it runs like charm (at least on my HD7970). The hand drawn cinematic, similar to those in Mirror's Edge, are really cool and hide the loading times pretty well. This is maybe the strongest feature of the game, it's technical side is amazing. Way better than expected.

The game then wants you to run. Its action it's extremely fast paced, demanding you to aim fast, shoot fast and think fast. It also demands you to search for health, to use objects in the map to cover from fire (sometimes there are so many enemies shooting at you that otherwise is impossible) while enemies moving to get you out of your cover without the regular magical mechanics of AAA shooters which regenerate health and let you stay there for ages. In 2013 all I can say is Hooray for Flying Wild Hog! Even AI is better than usual. It isn't smart, but it's very very aggressive. Even the weapons, which seem to be a bit lackluster at the beginning, are pretty good once you start upgrading them. And there's a huge difference between every weapon, making each of them good or bad depending on the situation. Again, well done.

So, if the game does so much things right, why does it fail? Because there are two important things that it does wrong. First one is the level design. Even if I love all the chances it gives to use map elements to kill the enemies, every level ends up being a corridor with some arenas in between and some secrets here and there. It's very Serious Sam-esque, but the design of every zone (specially in big arenas) is much worse. Sometimes really dull. It's not enough to leave me in an empty place with some objects and throw a bunch of enemies at me. To do that right you need a place that is awesome. For example, the town fight in one of the last levels of Serious Sam 3, or the different fights in the Egyptian ruins, are leagues beyond anything this game achieve.

But is not only the level design what is flawed, but the enemy design. I'm not only talking about aesthetics, but behavior. Some robots are cool (the one that charges on you), but some other are just dull and the game relies too much in throwing lots of them at you. Again, this works in Serious Sam because every enemy presents a different and well balanced threat. Here it doesn't. Also doesn't help that some of them, if they are a bit far from you, look a lot like the environment, making them difficult to be seen.

This two things lead to some very uninteresting fights, which considering this is a shooter is like a capital flaw.

Talking about the story... well, there's not too much to say. It doesn't help the game, neither kills it. Just an average one which is never very important for the enjoyment of the game.

Considering all of this, I cannot recommend it. And it's a shame, because it's a game I wanted to like, but I just don't enjoy it too much. That doesn't mean some other people won't enjoy it, because it still gets many things right, but here the scale is just a binary yes/no, so this one gets a no.

Anyway, Flying Wild Hog looks like a very promising studio. I'll take a look sooner or later at their Shadow Warrior, and I'll definitely wait for their next projects.

reviewText:
SHORT REVIEW:
The developers have no idea how to make a videogame.


LONG REVIEW:
I have no idea where to begin on how bad this game is. As a fan of mindless shooter, I can't fathom how flawed the game is in its core.

The character's movement does not feel the player is in control entirely to compensate the chaotic situations that the game constantly puts the player in, as sprinting and jumping are not very fluid. You cannot jump freely while sprinting, you lose a bit of handling while at it, and sprinting lasts for a very short period of time.
All of the enemies (and I mean all of them), have faster movement speed, usually 2 to 3 times faster than the character so the player is forced to be constantly moving with the game's awful controls.

The game seriously lacks variety of enemy types, but it also suffers from their flawed designs. Enemies should be very exciting to fight, but they are incredibly annoying to deal with.
There are self-destructive bots that move in an incredible speed whose explosion radius is massive, shockwave emitting crawlers which lock on you (for the most of the time you cannot avoid them easily) when charging at an accelerated speed, ranged gunners whose projectiles travel as fast as bullets, fast-moving rollers who charge at you to saw your limbs off, and other varieties of the said enemy types.

What's worse is that the game tends to put all of these annoying enemies in a single wave at once in which the player has to rely on variety of lucks or stupid AIs doing funky things to beat.
The game features about 3 different enemy types with different armor levels and different weapons on them. Some of these types have no weaknesses on how to kill them without almost dying. The game still gives you enough regen after a wave to restore back to perfect health, but it is no excuse to design a game where the player is meant to be hurt to almost death situations after every wave. This is the most frustrating part of the game. I died the average of 3 times per chapter, and  after those deaths I didnâ€™t bother changing a strategy and was still able to beat the level I had trouble with, because the enemy AIs were so unpredictable and had no counter-strategy to work with. It was all just luck for the most part. Explosion radius is bigger than the usual playerâ€™s predictions in the gameâ€™s FOV (and the game basically feeds on explosions), most of projectiles are semi-homing and they also explode dealing damage to the player around even though it misses, small enemies charge at you while you are dealing with bigger enemies and vice versa, and most of them donâ€™t have any counter-strategies to work with. One of my favorite mindless shooter is the Serious Sam series, and the game had enemies that were simply very fun to play against, so I can tell you that mindless shooter does not mean mindless design.

The level design is nothing of stellar, and sometimes makes no sense at all. The game has a hint system telling the player what to do, only when they reach a point. Here's why the hint system is completely useless:
There are points that emit green lights where the player has to go and interact with to advance in the level and it's ALWAYS just as simple as clicking on the button when they reach the point. However, the developers think the players lack brain so it tells them to â€œclick on the button to ... (insert any unnecessary information)â€. The problem is that the levels arenâ€™t designed well enough to sometimes let player know where to go in the dark environment, and the game does nothing to assist the player with. It tells the player to click on the button once they reach the only green-lit interactive interfaces which is completely useless. Later in the game, the levels have so many map decorations that are lit green with interfaces that cannot be interacted with. The players are accustomed to click on whatever that has an interface screen and green-lit, and the final levels of the game break this one rule that theyâ€™ve been training their players with. Often there will be times where it damages the player for absolutely no reason with some pre-scripted moving objects. There is no way to avoid them, and the game gives you a regen shortly after. Why were these put in the sequence in the first place?

The game looks pretty nice, but it is nothing of amazing. If the game was released on the consoles I doubt it would look as decent as any other average titles. I was playing this on my 780 Ti and I still experienced frame drops on chaotic situations, which the most of the game is in except when the player is walking to point A from point B. I can only assume the game is terribly optimized at best.

The game is the definition of frustration. There were so many flawed designs with no sense of innovation being found from the game, so I had to look up who in the world developed this terrible game. Flying Wild hog, as stupid as their name sounds, had no experience as it was their first game in the market. I will make sure to avoid any games from them in the future and so should anyone who wants to have fun with videogames.

reviewText:
Hard reset is a game that tries very hard to be like the old school shooters like Serious Sam, Pain killer, Duke and Shadow Warrior, unfortunately it falls very flat.

The story and writing are beyond awful, I can only assume it wasn't written by a English speaker as quite a lot of the dialogue is incorrect in English, getting an English localisation for your game is a very easy process, how that wasn't accomplished here is confusing to say the least.

The visual idenity of the game is confused, the style of props and materials don't fit well together at all, the enemy visual design blurs them into the background, the scale of the world is completely off and the FX are massively overdone to a point where sometimes you can't see. Not ideal for a game such as this.

The level design is attrocious, invisible walls everywhere, random elevators and doors everywhere that can't be opened till you eliminate the enemies (this can be grounded into the game in a much better way, the new Shadow warrior does exactly that).

On the plus side, the approach to physics and destruction is nice to see and the computer interfaces are pretty cool tech that isn't in enough games.

How this has a positive rating is beyond me, if you want to play a game like this that is actually good, go get Shadow Warrior (on further viewing, Shadow Waarrior is by the same developer, so definately skip this and just get Shadow Warrior)

reviewText:
This game is really good technically.  But is it actually fun to play?
It looks great, controls easily, and runs super-smoth.  This game reminds me a lot of Serious Sam packed into Doom 3 levels.  If that sounds like fun, go for it.  For me, an hour was about the extent of my enjoyment before it just felt like more and more of the same.

So do I recommend the game?  If you like this genre, I think it's really well made.  However, I felt like I had pretty much seen what the game had to offer after about an hour.  The levels are uninteresting.  The hordes of robots were boring.  It had none of the horror of Doom 3 but certainly the drab.  I don't think I am going to recommend this game, but it's not a bad offering for the genre.

reviewText:
This one came out of left field.

The game is visually fantastic and solid, featuring the benefits of modern FPS and Classic FPS design. The setting is especially well crafted with good voice acting and comic book style cutscenes telling the story.

It definitely derives influence from '80's and 90's science fiction such as Blade Runner and The Fifth Element. There's even a dash of Film Noir with the player character portrayed as a cynical authority figure.

Check this one out, it's more than worth it. Die-hards of the '90's online Arena shooters will appreciate it's run-and-gun gameplay and new players will enjoy the scalable and fair difficult curve as well as the entertaining narrative.

reviewText:
The basic Hard Reset experience is arcade-shooting action in a nutshell. You have only two guns, a gun that uses bullets and one that uses energy. However, the base guns (basicly rifles) have additional shotgun, gernade, mine-throwing, and various single power-shot modes that can be unlocked with points earned from kills and from scavenging yellow-glowing-box-things scattered throughout the levels. The varitions between similier modes for each gun are minor (the bullet-gun shotgun is slow and single-shot, the energy version is a wide spray of electricity for as long as you hold down the trigger), but the differences do add up.
Your only enemies are machines, which is good and bad. It's good if you like watching your target's armored body fall apart, but bad if you don't like bullet-spongy enemy. Several large foes take forever to kill. However, the degree of bullet sponge was acceptable to me, as per the enemies. The enemies themselves are limited for the first part of the game, which I liked because it made it easier to learn patterns, especially for large groups of enemies (there are several). The Enhanced content adds some new foes, however, and a flying version is both very deadly (it shoots back) and extremely annoying.
The combat in Hard Reset is the meat of the game, and is intense and demanding (many enemies focus on melee, meaning they throw themselves at you in large masses). Impediments to progess are all extremely basic keypad interacts that are thankfully less annoying than keycards. There is an extensive story, but I got sick of it early, and when the extended content shows up I'm pretty sure the whole thing stops making much sense, anyway.
If you like the momentum and skill required by games that utilize healthpacks over regenerating health, you will probably like this game.

reviewText:
I wanted this game to be good, I really did.  It looked really cool and had a lot of promise, but it just didn't deliver.  It's very pretty, yes, but that doesn't make a game any good.

The best analogy I can make for the problem is that the character is grossly overweight, because these are some issues:

A) He can't sprint more than 10 feet before having to catch his breath in between stuffing his face with mashed potatoes.
B) He can't crouch down because then all of his bacon cheeseburgers will fall out of his trenchcoat.
C) He can't stand on sloped surfaces without falling off, because he insists on carrying sticks of butter in his shoes for when the moment is right.
D) He scrambles to pick up his donuts every time an explosion goes off next to him, causing significant screen shaking

This, on top of extremely confusing map design and enemies whose animations are erratic and jump from pose to pose, as well as frustrating enemies that can often kill you before you realize what's even going on, the game was really not enjoyable to play.

reviewText:
The inspired art design can't make up for the repetitive and unengaging gameplay.

The level design (geometry, textures, effects) is frequently beautiful, very Blade Runner, at times, very original, although strangely low-poly.  The advertisements in particular are great: an original take that preserves a very cyberpunk feel.  But that's the end of what's good about Hard Reset.

There is little variety in enemies; what variety exists is largely about the size of their hitbox and what kind of weapon they use.  Every combat area is a predictably-sized arena with artificial sawtooths to prevent retreat, and doors that prevent continuing until all the bad guys are dead.  Many of the enemies have a lot more health than I personally find enjoyable.

The protagonist's weapons lack a certain oomph, maybe because all ten(?) of them are supposed to be flavors of only two transforming weapons-- so for instance, your proximity mine uses effects that look an awful lot like your plasma gun.  An experience point system unlocks new weapons and upgrades, but of course encourages upgrades, which in turn discourages variety; meanwhile, the fact that there's only two kinds of ammunition prevents the authors from meaningfully using ammunition to prompt weapon switching.

A lot of factors conspire to limit engagement with the game.  The voice acting sounds like the friends-and-family-of-the-devs style.  The story isn't the focus, of course, but what little exists doesn't help anything.  Occasional  trace-the-pipe puzzles and poor signposting wreak havoc with the pace.

Overall, this plays like a very very high-quality mod for a game ten or fifteen years old.  Which is a little like, Excellent cinemetography
date: considering that it's made for public access cable."  Might be of some interest for its take on cyberpunk
recommended: but it's not very engaging as a game."

reviewText: Hard Reset, oh boy. Though this game is a bit short, it is a fun (though nonsensical) sci-fi FPS. It is BRUTALLY diifficult: enemies prefer to use ambush tactics, come in big waves, and are quite capable of overwhelming the player. The player themselves has access to 2 weapons with 5 separate modes each, along with a secondary function for each mode. The CLN firearm is an advaned ballistic firearm, spewing bullets, mines, rockets, and grenades. The NRG weapon blasts rapidfire plasma orbs, plasma orbs that zap anything around them, shortrange lightning, tracking spheres, and it has a railgun mode. Ammo can be a bit tight in this game on occasion, however ammo for both guns regen if low enough, though this is rarely practical in combat.\n\nIn short, it is a brutal game, but a lot of fun, especially after a few weapon upgrades.

reviewText:
Hard Reset is definitely an old school style shooter.  The game gets fairly difficult at times so dying repeatedly in certain areas is to be expected.  The story isn't amazing but the cutscenes are done in animated comic book style which is pretty cool.  The original campaign isn't too long, but combined with the Exile DLC, this game becomes a bit lengthier.  Because the DLC adds on more levels without including more weapons/upgrades, the game becomes harder, especially if the upgrades chosen before entering the DLC levels were purely offensive like I did.  The enemies become much tankier so getting upgrades on health, defense, and ammo are definitely needed.  On the other hand, the level design were more varied, which is a plus, and felt better overall.

Technically, there are only two weapons, but each gun has multiple modes.  For example, one gun can transform from an assault rifle to a grenade launcher while the other can morph from traps to a rail gun.  Choosing the proper weapon and mode on the fly takes a while to get used to, but becomes fairly satisfying once you get the hang of it.  If your mouse has extra buttons, it's probably a good idea to hotkey the weapon swap to one of them as pressing the keys for it always felt a bit awkward for me.

It's got a decent length campaign mode as well as other replayable modes, which I haven't tried.  While the story isn't quite there, I would recommend this if you want to play an old school shooter game.

reviewText:
Overall a satisfying if brief game, set in a slightly bizarre futuristic cyberpunk world, where AI controlled machines have arisen as mankinds primary threat, fighting to gain entrance into the last bastion of human civilization.  The protagonist played is none other than a secret police type, send on missions to halt and uncover infiltrations and deal with them in a violent manner.

Sound great? Sadly, the storyline is a convoluted mess bordering on incomprehensible.  Having finished the game, I'm still not sure what was accomplished and what was going on.  With that major flaw aside, Hard Reset is an absolute blast, and captures the essence of the cyberpunk genre proficiently.

You're given 2 weapons from the word go, and as you progress through the game, granted fairly frequent upgrade to bolster their capabilities and fire modes, rather than replace them with completely new guns. We're not talking minor changes either. but rather unlocking things like charged blast to electro-mortar to smart-gun style upgrades, which you'll find yourself rapidly switching between mid-fight to use deadly combo's to turn otherwise difficult enemies into scrap.

The game starts out relatively difficult, almost to the point of being merciless, so if you're struggling, remember that in the future, lots of the cars, terminals and other machinery are highly volatile and explore with the gentlest of encouragement from your arsenal.

While the graphics are great, and the holographic style waepon upgrade interface is pretty cool,  I find it hard to overwhelmingly recommend this game due to the poor narrative. But, if you're the type to skip cutscenes, you'll probably find this worth your while.  There's potential here in the setting, so lets hope the developers make the most of it in any sequels.

reviewText:
1 hour in and I have already died at least 12 times and came at least 9. This game is â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing amazing. It is simple, harsh, brash, and wants to kill you in every it can. But I'll go through in an orderly manner.

Graphics;

The engine looks incredible. Light effects are believable, particle effects are phenomenal. The models and textures are gorgeous. Even down to the small things like wall posters and artwork.

Sound;

The sound effects are just like the game. Harsh, meaty, aggresive, and desperate to kill you.

Physics:

Best FPS physics I have seen in as long as I can remember. No I am not koking. I can shoot the top off a gas canister and watch it shoot off into a wall and explode. If I kill something while it's charging at me, it's corpse will continue flying at me.

Story:

The story is very cool make no mistake, but playing this for the story is like spending the night with Tori Black to play chess.

In summation, this game is a true old school shooter. Dark, gritty, hard and angry. Think of it like a combination of Unreal, Quake, Sin City, Serious Sam and Wolfenstein The New Order. Seriously.

Get it.

reviewText: Almost instantly Hard Reset brought to mind all those great late-90's FPS games. With a modern touch and great attention to detail, especially with the level design and enemy types, this game is truly both a blast from the past and a blast of fresh air. It is a shame that an amazing game like this has gone so unnoticed. I certainly am very glad that I decided to give it a go. Cool noir-ish style in its story, some very intriguing sci-fi concepts, fantastic gunplay and a gun-focused progression system, this game doesn't really lack anything. The gun system is interesting, you have two guns which have multiple modes of firing and you upgrade them as you go, also unlocking more fire modes, I think this system works very well combined with all the different enemies you'll face. I especially liked shooting the bigger enemies with a shotgun or a railgun, and seeing all the armor plating fly away, yet the buggers kept coming - so many thrilling fights! The boss fights are very enjoyable, the levels have lots of destructible environment and last but not least; this game has a lot of secret places - just like good old FPS games used to have. If you are a FPS fan, you should definitely play this one through.

reviewText: I had a lot of fun with this FPS. Set in a cyber punk styled world, the action is very fast paced with slick and polished visuals to really flesh out the environments. The combat mechanics really shine in this game with a good variety of weapons and enhancements that are upgraded throughout the game. The ability to dual wield weapons, each with a primary and secondary firing option means that there is a large enough variety of weapons that can used in combination to appeal to a wide range of play styles. My personal favourites are the crowd control options combined with a hard hitting attack.\n\nThe game story isn't much to write home about, but it provides enough of a  story inbetween frantic bouts of gun play. The long load times between deaths are overly long and probably my main criticism. Level design is well done with some interesting bosses and mechanics. I would say that the difficulty level on normal won't be too challenging for hardcore types, but is well balanced for regular players. The action is straight-up frantic without too much subtlty, so if you're looking for a more tactical or varied game style, you might want to look elsewhere. However, if games like Serious Sam or Pain Killer are more your style, you should definitely consider Hard Reset.

reviewText:
I picked up Hard Reset for very little during a Steam sale and I was impressed by it.  The game is a pure FPS shooter in which the player kills enemies and finds currency to purchase upgrades and weapons from terminals scattered throughout the levels.

Pros:
-very detailed dystopian environments
-good music and sound effects
-fun, challenging fights

Cons:
-weak story
-contrived voice acting for main character
-checkpoint saves, but felt adequate

The game took me ~10 hours to finish the campaign on normal and I believe there may be some replayability for those who would be interested in finding every secret" area.

Overall I would rate this game 7/10.  I had a lot of fun playing it and there wasn't much to complain about."

reviewText: Hard Reset provides a sugary love letter to fans of the no holds barred, 12 gun carrying, wall to wall shooting and explosions shooters of the past; however in doing so it still maintains a modern identity of its own.\nIn a market teeming with ironsight, cover system and squad command based first person shooter games (which are all of very high quality), it's intreresting to see a game chisel away the layers of peripheral gameplay features that have been slowly added one by one to make modern shooters what they are today and deliver a no nonsense fight-to-survive action rollercoaster. There's no aiming down sights, no taking cover or even crouching for that matter, no huge expansive environments, no mediocre plot that's trying to hard. There is a story and some really nice graphic novel-esque FMVs, but it's clear that this is a game all about playing.\nImagine anything from the family of original first person shooters like Wolfenstein or Quake, just with high end graphics and a weapon modulation and upgrade system. But the core of the game is just you, your gun and a boatload of mechanical gribblies that want to saw you to pieces. This is a very neat game.

reviewText: If you're tired of modern day FPS mechanics, you might want to check out Hard Reset . This is a game which sticks up a middle finger at chest high walls, regenerating health, weapon carry limits and waypoint markers, and takes us back to the glorious old school FPS days. You'll fight hordes of enemies in a cyberpunk city, where enclosed spaces makes the action challenging. The weapon upgrade system allows plenty of choice to suit your playing style. However its not all good. Although this is an indie game, I paid AAA price, so will judge by AAA standards. The story is poor, with dialogue filled with unexplained terms like quantum matrices and exterior AIs. It doesn't help that the game is only 4.5 hours long, and the ending comes literally out of nowhere, leaving what I understood of the plot feeling unresolved. The voiceacting is also quite lifeless. If you're looking for a mindless shooter, this could fill that need, but not at Â£22. Wait for a 50% off sale and then check it out.

reviewText:
Hard Reset gets a 8.5/10 from me, it's a good game. The only reason why there are some negative reviews is that this game is oldschool, meaning that you actually need skill and reflexes with a bit of tactic to survive.

So if you're a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ casual go back to your cave, if you want a good oldschool shooter that rewards skill rather than grind, hard reset is the game for you.

Let's start with the story: You are a cop/merc that has to kill all robots, thats basically it.

Graphics:  The levels are colorful and the graphics of this game are awesome, lots of ligth effects, screenshake, uber physics, you can basically destzory everthing that is not attached to another object.

Enemies: A bit monotone but require reflexes and the right tactic.

Gunplay feels good, with some weapons being less rewarding than others, overall motivation is also good, exploring levels is quite well rewarded and you always look for more upgrades.

I picked this game up for 3 bucks and had awesome fun with it, wish there were more games with this palystyle and graphics today, you won't find a better shooter for this price at the moment, devs even gave out a DLC for it.

reviewText:
A couple of hours playing this and I am having a great time. A really nice cyberpunk setting and despite the fact that I am using a 3 year old graphics card at the moment and there is a hell of a lot going on visually it is running beautifully.
I very much get the impresion this is a game that knows what it is and is not trying to be something it isn't. It is basically a twitch shooter with loads of bad guys. ok robots, and loads of shooting. Yes it is a corridoor shooter but that is not always a bad thing and unlike a lot of games it is not pretending to be anything else.
I love big open world sandpit games like Farcry and Skyrim and first person rpg shooters being a huge Deus Ex fan (I refuse to acknowledge the second one as a Deus Ex game it would be too painfull ). However I also like a good old style shooter where I can just dive in for an hour or two and blow the hell out of everything that moves and to me that is exactly what this is.  They are not east to do well, just look at the abomination that was Duke Nukem Forever,  and this one has been done well and is fun.
If you want great story and character development forget it there isn't either. However if you want a good fun fps with a great graphical feel that knows exactly what it is and does it well buy and have fun. If you look at what this developer has gone on to do since with the new Shadow Warrior you can see they have a real understanding of the genre.
Playing this takes me back to the likes of Duke Nukem 3D, the origional Shadow Warrior and Serious Sam with his BFG (We all know the F stood for Friendly, honest...) So lock and load, hold down the trigger and send those bots to that great scrapyard beyond the mechanical veil.

reviewText:
TL;DR below

10 minutes in and I was bored, 30 minutes in and I was hooked.

Hard Reset is no more or less than the quintessential old school shooter. It lacks any real form of cover, leaning, and most shockingly crouch, and the maps are incredibly linear. There's no notion of stealth or sniping or any serious problem solving. It's a very spam-y game. You just take on waves of enemies as they come. There are different sorts of enemies, but it doesn't matter much in terms of just sinking enough ammo into them until they die.

Enemies drop four kinds of drops: health (green), rifle ammo (red), plasma gun ammo (blue), and nano (orange). You also have a shield but it regenerates automatically. You collect enough nano and you earn an upgrade. Both of your weapons as well as your general gear upgrade the same way. Everything has 5 modes (the last two of which get unlocked later) and each mode has 2 additional upgrades beyond the first for a total of 15 upgrades for each weapon and your gear. For weapons this tends to mean a primary attack, and secondary function or attack, and a passive bonus in each of the 5 modes. Each weapon uses the same ammunition for each attack and each mode, albeit at different rates.

Your environment is pretty dangerous, there are high explosives all over the place as well as electrified items which, when damaged, shock everything within range for a period of time before exploding. Additional from time to time you encounter random flame-throwers in the walls. You can take down entire waves of enemies with just the explosive and electric death traps lying around.

That's basically it. That's the entire game (as far as I've played it anyway).

On the down-side, the gun play isn't all that imaginative and you don't always have time to swap to all your cool new upgrades in the heat of battle. This combined with the high linearity, wave format of enemy encounters, terrible terrible voice acting and story (not that it has any real impact on the game), and the fact that, despite what the pictures look like above, the artistic style really isn't all that nice, makes me sort of sigh and dream of what this game could have been.

IMHO, what this game could have been is Shadow Warrior (Redux), which I believe was a perfect and shining example of what happens when you put modern game technology and philosophy into an old school shooter. In a sense, Hard Reset is like a poor man's Shadow Warrior. Definitely not worth the same amount of money (I just picked up Hard Reset for like 2.50 USD, sooo not complaining). On the upside though, if you do like your old school shooters, this is a good game. It does what it sets out to do. It's fun, it's destructive, it's fast paced (during combat sequences), and you can just go insane. Ammo conservation hasn't been a problem yet (normal difficulty). Over all, I haven't found the game to be really difficult at all, which is not to say that I haven't died yet. Bottom line is, I'm enjoying it, I'd recommend it, and though I haven't played it enough to comment on the complaints about its short length, I'd say even at full cost (15 USD) I think it's fair.

TL;DR : Solid game, proper old school shooter experience, no major faults besides â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ story and acting, but nothing mind blowing either. I'd recommend it to friends.

reviewText:
Cyberpunk asthetic, beautiful graphics, and intense gameplay make for a thrilling FPS.

Hard Reset sets out to let you slaughter tons of robots in a series of thrilling encounters throughout a gorgeous cyberpunk city, and it does so with style. From the main menu to the upgrade stations, everything carries the futuristic cyberpunk asthetic, which greatly enhances the atmosphere. The city and robot design are gorgeous, and with a great use of color, lighting, and effects.

You have two weapons to quickly switch between, and each weapon can morth into upto four different guns, such as an assault rifle, shotgun, grenade launcher, and rocket launcher. As you progress you can unlock additional modes for each gun and upgrades for each mode.

The battles are fast, furious, and intense. Circle strafe and keep moving, as standing still will get you killed. I found the normal difficulty perfect, challenging enough to make every fight intense, but I would only die maybe once per level. Additional checkpoints have been added since release to minimize repeating encounters upon death. The game is a good length, wrapping up before it becomes repetitive or outlives its welcome.

The main faults I found were the lack of a manual save - I shouldn't have to rely on checkpoints - and that the story was rather confusing and mostly told between levels.

reviewText:
Hard Reset is an intense first-person shooter that takes place in a futuristic cyberpunk envoirnment and city. To play it, you're going to want at least three things: A desire to shoot countless hordes of robots, patience of iron, and a pretty powerful graphics card. If you don't have one or more of these things, Hard Reset probably isn't for you.

This game has a really awesome art style, both the beautiful enviornments that you play in, and the cutscenes that play at the beginning of a level. The cutscenes themselves play like a sci-fi comic book, which I think is really neat, though most of the time it doesn't feel like there's much story involved. The gameplay itself is oldschool right down to the bare bones, sort of a hybrid of painkiller, doom and serious sam. You'll engage in plenty of hardcore combat with all sorts of robots that appear throughout the levels and try to kill them by any means necessary, whether it be mowing them down with your weapons, or blowing up enviornmental hazards around them, ranging from barrels, electrical machines, cars...you get the idea.

Probably one of the coolest features of Hard Reset is that, unlike most oldschool shooters, you don't actually collect new guns. Instead, you get to power up the weapons and gear the game starts you out with by collecting Nanos, then going to upgrade machines to select the upgrades you desire. For example, you can upgrade your assault rifle to be things like a shotgun and an rpg, and you can improve the quality of your armor and health, to name a few things. Nanos can be collected by killing enemies, looking throughout the levels, and finding secrets by looking high and low for them and blowing up walls.

Even though I really like Hard Reset, I'll admit it's not for everyone---it can get rather frustrating at times, since enemies often appear in swarms really quickly and can often result in stupid deaths (though to be fair, I AM playing on insane difficulty), and the game does have very little story (mostly just kill machines and complete objectives). Very highly recommended for those who love intense oldschool gameplay and cyberpunk/sci-fi games, though. 3.5/5.0

reviewText: Oh to go back to the days of just wasting through baddies moving from checkpoint to checkpoint. This game has done wonders  to bring that feeling back, only now with a new coat of paint of todays tech to sweeten the deal. There are holo-ad signs( which can be used offensivly by shooting them) which give you a glimps of what might the inhabitants might have filled there days with. You run through city scapes filled with parked( or abandoned) cars ( which can be destroyed hurting you or enemies) , many nooks and crannies to root around in to find secrets, blimps and other air vehicles flying over head, and announcments looped through loud speakers further adding to the meat of the world. You have two weapons , or should i say weapon types; being that either one can be upgraded to have an added mode to it. the types are solid rounds and energy munitions; bothe can be upgraded to fill the rolls of straight shooter( solid : assault rifle with zoom secondary/ energy : pulse rifle with charge blaster secondary) close range crowd control ( solid : shot gun with multy shot burst secondary / energy : multi arc electricity emiter with stun burst for secondary). All can be upgraded at stations that are littered about levels, you must spend an upgrade point( gained by filling an upgrade bar to full by picking up packets from either downing baddies or finding them in secret areas) on either of the 2 gun types to unlock each of their modes and some slight upgrades for each of the modes, or a point on your armor un locking many bonuses like more health , more damage soak, or faster regen of sprint. even the upgrade stations do not take you out of the world, the staton's menu is diplayed as a holographic projection, and your cross hair turns into a curser for making selctions. If you want to back out of the upgrade menu just walk away from the station and continue mayhem. All in all this is some great adreniline pumping action with a very fleshed out world to blow stuff up in.

reviewText:
Hard Reset is an FPS with more in common with old school shooters than it does with the more modern varient that has been popular recently. The game has a unique weapons system which utilizes two different guns each having 5 weapon modes each, meaning that in escense you have 10 guns, a far cry from the 2 that you are usually permitted to carry.

The style of the game is dark sci-fi and pits you against robotic enemies or varying sizes, shapes and funcations. There's an interesting amount of different levels although visually there is very little to seperate them and this can make them a little difficult to navigate at times. The difficulty with navigation is that you can basically end up getting stuck for where to go and end up scratching your head for a long amount of time.

Other than a slight repetativeness to the level design and gameplay Hard Reset is still a fun game to play through, especially if you're an old school shooter fan with a lot of tolerance for faults.

Review update: beat the main campaign, haven't played DLC yet.

This game is pretty insane. If you like old school FPS, or are itching for a good cyberpunk game (of which there seem to be few) then check out Hard Reset. Made by Polish devs who made their own engine, this game looks awesome and plays great. Visually very impressive for a cyberpunk universe. My one knock is I found the story a bit convoluted and hard to follow, which is a little sad because the visuals are so good. Anyhow it's your basic story of man vs. killer machines. The gameplay is where it's at. Awesome weapon mods. Grenades that create a vortex to pull in enemies, laser guided rockets, energy mortars and rail guns. The VFX on the NRG weapon are simply amazing. I found it brutally challenging and fun on hard difficulty (cause how could you play a game called Hard Reset on Medium or Easy?...)

8/10 worth it
